‰∏ÄÊòØÂÖ®ÊñáÊú¥ÂÆûÊó†ÂçéÁöÑË°åÊñáÈ£éÊ†º„ÄÇ‰πüËÆ∏Âõ†‰∏∫ÊòØÂè£Ëø∞Êï¥ÁêÜÁöÑÁºòÊïÖÔºåÂÖ®ÊñáÂπ∂Êú™ÊúâÁ≤æÂ∑ßÁöÑÁ´†Ê≥ïÁªìÊûÑÔºåËØª‰∏ãÊù•Á°ÆÂÆûÊòØ‰∏é‰∫∫‰∫§Ë∞à‰πãÊÑüÔºåÊèèÂÜô‰∫≤ÂàáÂèà‰∏çÂ§±ÂáÜÁ°Æ„ÄÇ ‰∫åÊòØ‰ª§‰∫∫‰∏çÁ¶ÅÊãçÊâãÁß∞Â¶ôÁöÑÈáëÂè•„ÄÇ‰π¶‰∏≠Êúâ‰∫õÂè•Â≠êÔºå‰πüËÆ∏ÊòØÂõ†‰∏∫Ë°åÊñáÈ£éÊ†ºÁöÑÁºòÊïÖÔºåÊÑüËßâ„ÄåÂπ≥Âπ≥Êó†Â•á„ÄçÔºå‰ΩÜÂ∞±ÊòØËÆ©‰∫∫ËßâÂæóÂ¶ôÔºåËøô‰∫õÂè•Â≠êÂÉèÊòØÊ≠¶ÊûóÈ´òÊâãÁöÑÁÇπÁ©¥ÔºåÁúã‰ººËΩªËΩªÂ∑ßÂ∑ßÔºåÂç¥ËÆ©‰∫∫Âä®Âºπ‰∏çÂæó„ÄÇ ÊØîÂ¶ÇË∞àÂà∞Âõæ‰π¶È¶ÜÔºå‰ΩïÂÖàÁîüËØ¥Âπ¥ËΩªÊó∂Ôºå„ÄåÊØè‰∏™Âë®Êú´ÔºåÊàëÈÉΩ‰ºöÈ™ëÁùÄËá™Ë°åËΩ¶ÂéªÂåóÂπ≥Âõæ‰π¶È¶ÜÂÄü‰π¶Ôºå‰∏ÄÂÄüÂ∞±ÊòØ‰∫îÊú¨ÔºåËøôÂ∞±ÊòØ‰∏ÄÊòüÊúüÁöÑÁ≤æÁ•ûÈ£üÁ≤ÆÔºå‰∏ãÂë®ÂÜçÂéª„ÄÇ„ÄçË∞àÂà∞Áé∞Âú®ÁöÑÂõæ‰π¶È¶ÜÔºå‰ªñËØ¥Ôºå„ÄåÂõæ‰π¶È¶ÜÁöÑ‰ΩúÁî®ÊòØ‰ªÄ‰πàÔºüÂ∫îËØ•ÊòØÂ∞ΩÊúÄÂ§ßÁöÑÂèØËÉΩÊää‰π¶ËÆ©Â§ßÂÆ∂ÁúãÂà∞„ÄÇÂèØÊòØÊåâÁÖßÊàë‰ª¨Áé∞Âú®ÁöÑËßÇÁÇπÔºåÂõæ‰π¶ÊòØÂõΩÂÆ∂ÁöÑË¥¢ÂØåÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Ë¶ÅÂ∞ΩÈáèÂú∞ÊääÂÆÉ‰øùÊä§Â•ΩÔºåË∂äÁøªË∂äÁÉÇÊÄé‰πàÊàêÔºü„Äç ÂÜçÊØîÂ¶ÇÁé∞Âú®Â∏∏Ë¢´ÊèêËµ∑ÁöÑ„ÄåÂç∑„ÄçÔºå‰ΩïÂÖàÁîü‰πüÊúâ‰∏ÄÊÆµÁ≤æÂΩ©ÁöÑËØÑËø∞Ôºö ÂåÖÊã¨Áé∞Âú®‰πüÊòØËøôÊ†∑ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÊÄªÊúâ‰∏ÄÁßçËêΩÂêéÁöÑÂÜúÊ∞ëÊÑèËØÜÔºåËÄÅÊÉ≥ÁùÄÊãºÂëΩÔºåÂº∫Ë∞É„ÄåÂêÉÂ§ßËã¶ÔºåËÄêÂ§ßÂä≥„ÄçÔºåÂèØÊòØËøõÊ≠•‰∏çËÉΩÂÖâÈù†Ëøô‰∏™Ôºå‰∏çÁÑ∂Êï¥‰∏™‰∫∫Á±ªÊñáÂåñËÉΩËøõÊ≠•Â§öÂ∞ëÔºüÂâç‰∫õÂπ¥Êàë‰ª¨ËøòÊèêËøá„ÄåË∂ÖËã±Ëµ∂Áæé„ÄçÔºå‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàË¶ÅË∂ÖÂÆÉÔºü‰∏çÂ∞±ÊòØÂÆÉÊØî‰Ω†ÂÖàËøõ„ÄÇÂèØÂÆÉ‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàÂÖàËøõÔºüÈöæÈÅìËã±ÂõΩ‰∫∫„ÄÅÁæéÂõΩ‰∫∫Êôö‰∏äÈÉΩ‰∏çÁù°ËßâÔºü„ÄåÊª°Èù¢ÊµÅÊ±óÔºåÁªàÁîüËçÜÊ£ò„ÄçÔºåËøôÊòØ„ÄäÂú£Áªè„ÄãÈáåÁöÑËØùÔºå„ÄåÈù¢ÊúùÈªÑÂúüÔºåËÉåÊúùÂ§©„ÄçÔºå‰∏≠ÂõΩ‰∫∫Âπ≤‰∫Ü‰∫îÂçÉÂπ¥ÔºåÂèØËã±ÂõΩÂéÜÂè≤Êâç‰∏ÄÂçÉÂπ¥ÔºåÁæéÂõΩËøû‰∫îÁôæÂπ¥ÈÉΩÊ≤°ÊúâÔºåÂì•‰º¶Â∏ÉÂèëÁé∞Êñ∞Â§ßÈôÜÊâç‰∫îÁôæÂπ¥ÔºåÂÆÉ‰ª¨‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàÂÖàËøõÔºüÊàë‰ª¨‰∏≠ÂõΩ‰∫∫Âè£ÊòØËã±ÂõΩ‰∫∫Âè£ÁöÑ‰∫åÂçÅÂÄçÔºåËã±ÂõΩÊâçÂÖ≠ÂçÉ‰∏á‰∫∫ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÂçÅ‰∏â‰∫ø‰∫∫ÔºåË¶ÅËÆ∫Ëµ∑Êó©Ë¥™ÈªëÂºÄÂ§úËΩ¶ÁöÑËØùÔºåÊàë‰ª¨‰∏çÁü•ÈÅìÂ∫îËØ•ÊØîÂÆÉÈ´òÊòéÂ§öÂ∞ëÔºåÂèØÊòØËøë‰ª£ÁöÑ‰ºüÂ§ßÂºÄÂàõËÄÖÔºåÂÉèÁâõÈ°ø„ÄÅËææÂ∞îÊñáÔºåÂåÖÊã¨È©¨ÂÖãÊÄùÔºåÈÉΩÊòØÂá∫Ëá™Ëã±ÂõΩÔºåËÄå‰∏çÊòØÂú®‰∏≠ÂõΩ„ÄÇ‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàÔºüÊòØÊàë‰ª¨‰∏≠ÂõΩ‰∫∫ÊáíÊÉ∞Ôºü‰∏çËÉΩÈÇ£‰πàËØ¥„ÄÇÊùéÊîøÈÅì‰∫åÂçÅ‰πù‚Ä¶  ( 2 min )
    Êó†Ê≥ïÂá∫Ê∏∏ÔºüÈÇ£Â∞±ÊääÊÉ≥ÂéªÁöÑÂú∞ÊñπÁªüÁªüÊ†áËÆ∞‰∏ãÊù•ÔºåÁ≠âÂæÖËÉΩÁé©ÈÇ£Â§©ÔΩúÂú∞Âõæ

ÊâÄ‰ª•ËøëÊúüÂèëÁé∞‰∫Ü„ÄäExping„ÄãËøô‰∏™Âú∞ÂõæÊ†áËÆ∞Â∫îÁî®Êó∂ÔºåÊ¨£Âñú‰πãÊÉÖ‰∏çË®ÄËÄåÂñª„ÄÇ ‰∫∫‰ª¨ÂèØ‰ª•Âú®Exping‰∏äÊ†áËÆ∞Âú∞ÁÇπ„ÄÅÁîüÊàêÂú∞ÂõæËøõË°åÂàÜ‰∫´„ÄÇ‰πüÂèØ‰ª•ÁúãÂà∞ÂÖ∂‰ªñ‰∫∫ÂÖ¨ÂºÄÂàÜ‰∫´ÁöÑÂêÑÁßç‰∏ªÈ¢òÂú∞ÂõæÔºåÊØîÂ¶ÇÂíñÂï°Âú∞Âõæ„ÄÅÂæíÊ≠•Âú∞Âõæ„ÄÅÁæéÈ£üÂú∞ÂõæÁ≠âÔºåÂØπ‰∫éÂèóÁñ´ÊÉÖÂΩ±ÂìçÂè™ËÉΩÂú®Êú¨Âú∞Êé¢Á¥¢ÁöÑ‰∫∫Êù•ËØ¥ÔºåÁÆÄÁõ¥ÊòØÁªù‰Ω≥ÁöÑÊé¢Â∫óÊåáÂçó„ÄÇ ‰∏çËøáÂêéÁª≠Êàë‰πüÂèëÁé∞ÔºåÁ±ª‰ººÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®Âπ∂‰∏çÂ∞ëÔºåÁôæÂ∫¶Âú∞ÂõæÂíåÈ´òÂæ∑Âú∞Âõæ‰πüÊúâÁ±ª‰ººÁöÑÂÆöÂà∂Âú∞ÂõæÂäüËÉΩÔºå‰ΩìÈ™å‰∏äÂêÑÊúâÂçÉÁßãÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•ËøôÈáåÊàë‰πüÊîæ‰∏ÄËµ∑ÊØîËæÉÔºåÂ∏åÊúõËÉΩÂ∏ÆÂà∞Ë∑üÊàë‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÂñúÊ¨¢Êé¢Â∫óÊâìÂç°ÁöÑÂèãÂèãÔΩû ÊàëÂØπËøôÁ±ªÂ∫îÁî®ÁöÑ‰∏ªË¶ÅËØâÊ±ÇÊúâËøô3‰∏™Ôºö 1„ÄÅËÉΩÂáÜÁ°ÆÊêúÂà∞Âú∞ÁÇπÂπ∂Ê†áËÆ∞ 2„ÄÅËÉΩÂáÜÁ°ÆÂØºËà™Âà∞ËØ•Âú∞ÁÇπ 3„ÄÅÂàÜ‰∫´ÁªôÊúãÂèãÂêéÔºåÊúãÂèãËÉΩÂú®Ëá™Â∑±ÁöÑÂú∞ÂõæËΩØ‰ª∂ÊâìÂç°Âπ∂Êî∂Ëóè ÊâÄ‰ª•‰∏ãÈù¢‰πü‰ºöÊåâÁÖßËøô3‰∏™Ê†áÂáÜÊù•ÂàÜÊûêÂ∫îÁî®Ôºå‰∫ã‰∏çÂÆúËøüÔºåÈ©¨‰∏äÂºÄÂßãÔΩû ExpingÔºöÁî®Êà∑ÁÉ≠Áà±ÂàÜ‰∫´ÔºåÊúâÂæàÂ§ö‰∏ªÈ¢òÂú∞ÂõæÂèØ‰ª•ÂéªÊé¢Á¥¢ Ê†áËÆ∞Âú∞ÁÇπ Â∞ùËØï‰∫ÜÂá†‰∏™Âú∞ÁÇπÈÉΩËÉΩÂáÜÁ°ÆÊêúÁ¥¢Âà∞„ÄÇ Áº∫ÁÇπÊòØÂú∞Âõæ‰ø°ÊÅØÊØîËæÉÂ∞ëÔºåÂ¶Ç‰∏ãÊâÄÁ§∫ÔºåÂêåÊ†∑ÊòØÂÆö‰ΩçÂà∞ÂπøÂ∑ûÂåó‰∫¨Ë∑ØÔºåÊòéÊòæÂ∑¶ÂõæÈ´òÂæ∑Âú∞ÂõæÁöÑ‰ø°ÊÅØÊØîÂè≥ÂõæÁöÑexping‰∏∞ÂØåÂ§ö‰∫Ü„ÄÇ ‰ºòÁÇπÊòØÊ†áËÆ∞Âú∞ÁÇπÊó∂ÔºåÈô§‰∫ÜÊñáÊú¨ÊèèËø∞Â§ñÔºåËøòÂèØ‰ª•Ê∑ªÂä†ÂõæÁâá„ÄÅÊ†áÁ≠æ„ÄÅËØÑÂàÜÔºå‰ªéÂ§ö‰∏™Áª¥Â∫¶ÁÇπËØÑËØ•Âú∞ÁÇπ„ÄÇËøô‰πüÊúâÂä©‰∫éÁî®Êà∑‰ªéÂ§ö‰∏™ÊñπÈù¢Êù•‰∫ÜËß£ËØ•Â∫ó„ÄÇ ÂØºËà™Âú∞ÁÇπ expingÂΩìÂâçÊ≤°ÊúâÂØºËà™ÂäüËÉΩÔºåÂΩìÁÇπÂáªÂØºËà™Êó∂Ôºåexping‰ºöÂºïÂØºÁî®Êà∑ÊâìÂºÄÂÖ∂‰ªñÂú∞ÂõæËøõË°åÂØºËà™„ÄÇ     ‰Ω†Á¶ªÈù†ÂÜô‰ΩúÂÖªÊ¥ªËá™Â∑±ËøòÊúâÂ§öËøúÔºü
    ÂºïÂ≠ê ÊàëÊòØJeff/Ëä±ÁîüÈÖ±Ôºå‰∏ÄÂêç‰∫ßÂìÅÁªèÁêÜÔºåÂÖºËÅåÂÜÖÂÆπÂàõ‰ΩúËÄÖÔºå‰∏ªË¶ÅËæìÂá∫ÊñáÂ≠ó„ÄÇ ËøáÂéª‰∫îÂπ¥ÔºåÊàë‰∏ÄÁõ¥Âú®Êé¢Á¥¢ÔºöËÉΩÂê¶Êúâ‰∏ÄÂ§©Èù†ÂÖ®ËÅåÂÜô‰ΩúÊù•ÂÖªÊ¥ªËá™Â∑±„ÄÇ ÊÅ∞ÈÄ¢‚ÄúÂ∞èÊä•Á´•‚ÄùÁ≠â‰ªòË¥π‰∫ßÂìÅÈôÜÁª≠ÈóÆ‰∏ñÔºå‰∏∫ÂÜô‰ΩúÂïÜ‰∏öÂåñÊèê‰æõ‰∫ÜÊñ∞ÁöÑÂèØËÉΩÊÄß„ÄÇ ÊàëÊÉ≥ÔºåÊòØ‰∏™Â•ëÊú∫ÂÆåÊï¥ËÅäËÅäÊàëÁé∞Èò∂ÊÆµÁöÑÁúãÊ≥ï‰∫Ü„ÄÇ ‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàË¶ÅËØïÁùÄÈù†ÂÜô‰ΩúÂÖªÊ¥ªËá™Â∑±Ôºü ‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàË¶ÅËØïÁùÄÈù†ÂÜô‰ΩúÂÖªÊ¥ªËá™Â∑±Ôºü ÊàëÊÉ≥‰ªéÊõ¥Êú¨Ë¥®ÁöÑËßíÂ∫¶ÁªôÂá∫Áé∞Èò∂ÊÆµÁöÑÁ≠îÊ°à---Âç≥ÔºåÂÖàÂÆö‰πâ‚ÄúÂÖªÊ¥ªËá™Â∑±‚Äù„ÄÇ ÊâÄ‰ª•ÔºåÂÖàË∞àË∞à‚ÄúË¥¢ÂØå‚Äù‰∏é‚ÄúÂÖªÊ¥ªËá™Â∑±‚ÄùÁöÑÊ†áÂáÜ„ÄÇ ‰∫∫Â§©ÁîüÂØπ‰∏§‰ª∂‰∫ãÊä±ÊúâÊâßÂøµÔºå‰∏Ä‰ª∂ÊòØ‚ÄúËá™Áî±‚ÄùÔºåÂè¶‰∏Ä‰ª∂ÊòØ‚ÄúÊ≠£Á°Æ‚Äù„ÄÇ ÂØπ‚ÄúËá™Áî±‚ÄùÂíå‚ÄúÊ≠£Á°Æ‚ÄùÁöÑÊâßÂøµÈ©±Âä®‰∫∫ÊàêÈïøÔºå‰ΩÜ‰πüÂΩ¢ÊàêÂéãÂäõ„ÄÇÂ∞§ÂÖ∂ÊòØÂú®Ëøô‰∏§‰ª∂‰∫ãÁöÑÂéãÂäõÂè†Âä†Êó∂Ôºå‰ºöÂèòÂæóÊõ¥ÂèØÊÄï„ÄÇ ÊàëÂíåÂæàÂ§ö‰∫∫‰∏ÄÊ†∑Ôºå‰ª•‚ÄúË¥¢ÂØåËá™Áî±‚Äù‰∏∫ÁõÆÊ†áÂéªÂ•ãÊñóÔºå‰ΩÜÂèà‰∏çÁü•ÈÅìË¥¢ÂØåÂ§öÂà∞‰ªÄ‰πàÁ®ãÂ∫¶‰∏∫‚ÄúËá™Áî±‚ÄùÔºå‰ª•ÂèäÔºå‚ÄúËá™Áî±‚ÄùÁöÑËá™Â∑±ËØ•Ëøá‰ΩïÁßçÁîüÊ¥ª„ÄÇÂÜçÂä†‰∏äÂØπ‚ÄúÊ≠£Á°Æ‚ÄùÁöÑÊâßÂøµÔºåÂñúÊ¨¢Áî®Â≠¶ÁîüÊÄùÁª¥ÂéªËØª‰π¶ÂíåÊ±ÇÊïôÔºå‰ΩÜÊúÄÁªàÂèëÁé∞Á≠îÊ°à99%ÂèñÂÜ≥‰∫éËá™Ë∫´Ôºå‰∏î‰º¥ÈöèÁùÄËá™Ë∫´ÊàêÈïøÔºåÁ≠îÊ°à‰πüÈÄêÊ≠•ÊºîÂèò„ÄÅÊçâÊë∏‰∏çÈÄè„ÄÇ‰∏§‰ªΩÊâßÂøµÂè†Âä†‰πã‰∏ãÔºå‰∏ÄËæπÂØπ‰∏çËá™Áî±ÁöÑÁîüÊ¥ªÊÑüÂà∞ÁÑ¶ËôëÔºå‰∏ÄËæπÂõ†Êú™ÊâæÂà∞Ë¢´ËÆ§ËØÅÁöÑ‚ÄúÊ≠£Á°Æ‚ÄùËß£Ê≥ïÊÑüÂà∞‰∏çÂÆâÔºåÊúÄÁªàÔºåÁÆóÊòØ‰∏™ÊúâÊÑèËøõÂèñÁöÑ‰∫∫ÔºåÂç¥ÂèçÂÄí‰∏çÂπ∏Á¶è„ÄÇ ËøõÂèñÁöÑ‰∫∫ÂèçÂÄí‰∏çÂπ∏Á¶èÔºüËøáÂéª‰∏§Âπ¥ÔºåÊàë‰∏ÄÁõ¥ËØïÂõæÂØªÊâæËøô‰∏™ÂëΩÈ¢ò/ÊÇñËÆ∫ÁöÑËß£Ê≥ï„ÄÇ ÁÑ¶ËôëÂíå‰∏çÂÆâÂè™Âõ†‰∏çÂ§üÂÖ∑‰ΩìÔºåÂê∏ÂºïÁùÄÊàë‰ª¨ÁöÑ‚ÄúËá™Áî±‚ÄùÂíå‚ÄúÊ≠£Á°Æ‚ÄùÔºåÊàñËÆ∏Âè™ÊòØ‰∏§‰∏™‰∏çÂ≠òÂú®ÁöÑÊ®°Á≥äÂπªË±°„ÄÇÊâÄ‰ª•ÊàëËÄÉËôëÁî®Ââ™ÊûùÁöÑÁ≠ñÁï•ÔºåÊää‰∏çÂ§üÂÖ∑‰ΩìÂíåÁ°ÆÂÆöÁöÑÊù°‰ª∂Á†çÊéâÔºåÁúãÁúãËøô‰∏§‰ª∂‰∫ãËÉåÂêéÁöÑÁúüÂÆûÂëΩÈ¢ò„ÄÇ Ë¶ÅÂ∞ÜËøô‰∏§‰∏™ÂπªË±°ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÂåñÔºåË¶ÅÊòéÁ°Æ‰∏§‰∏™ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÊ¶ÇÂøµÔºöÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÔºå‰Ωï‰∏∫Ë¥¢ÂØåÔºåËøõ‰∏ÄÊ≠•Ôºå‰Ωï‰∏∫‰Ω†Ê≠§ÁîüËßâÂæóË∂≥Â§üÁöÑË¥¢ÂØå„ÄÇÁ¨¨‰∫åÔºå‰Ωï‰∏∫Ëá™Áî±Ôºå‰ª•ÂèäÔºå‰Ω†ÊÉ≥Â∞ÜËá™Áî±ÁöÑÊó∂Èó¥ÊäïÂêë‰ΩïÂ§Ñ„ÄÇ‰∏çÊòéÁ°ÆËøô‰∏§‰∏™ÈóÆÈ¢òÁöÑÁ≠îÊ°àÔºåË¥¢ÂØåÁöÑÁõÆÊ†áÂ∞ÜÊó†ÈôêËÜ®ËÉÄÔºåËá™Áî±ÁöÑÊó∂Èó¥Â∞ÜË¢´Êµ™Ë¥πÔºåË¥¢ÂØåËá™Áî±Â∞±ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏çÂèØËêΩÂú∞ÁöÑÂπªÊÉ≥„ÄÇ ÂØπ‰∫éË¥¢ÂØåÁöÑÁõÆÊ†áÔºåÊàëÊ≤°ÊúâÂàíÂÆö‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÁöÑÊï∞Â≠ó„ÄÇ ÂéüÂõ†ÊòØÔºåÊàë‰∏çÁ°Æ‚Ä¶  ( 2 min )
    Â¶Ç‰ΩïÂú®‰∫íËÅîÁΩëÈ´òÊïàÊêúÁ¥¢‰ø°ÊÅØÔºüÂÖ≥‰∫éÊêúÁ¥¢ÂºïÊìéÁöÑÂàÜ‰∫´‰∏éÊÄªÁªì
    Ë¶ÅËØ¥Âú®‰∏≠ÂõΩÁü•ÂêçÂ∫¶ÊúÄÈ´òÁöÑÁΩëÁ´ôÔºåÁôæÂ∫¶Â∫îËØ•ÊòØÂΩì‰πãÊó†ÊÑßÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÂêçÔºõË¶ÅËØ¥Êàë‰ª¨Êó•Â∏∏‰ΩøÁî®ÊúÄÈ¢ëÁπÅÁöÑÁΩëÁ´ôÔºåÂ∞ΩÁÆ°ÊØè‰∏™‰∫∫ÁöÑ‰ΩøÁî®‰π†ÊÉØ‰∏éÂ∑•‰ΩúÈúÄÊ±Ç‰∏çÂêåÔºåÂêÑÂ§ß‰∏ªÊµÅÊêúÁ¥¢ÂºïÊìé‰æùÊóßÂêçÂàóÂâçËåÖ„ÄÇ‰ΩÜÊòØÔºå‰Ω†ÁúüÁöÑ‰∫ÜËß£Ëøô‰∫õÂäüËÉΩÂº∫Â§ß„ÄÅÂú®‰Ω†ÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÂ≠¶‰π†‰∏≠‰∏çÂèØÊàñÁº∫ÁöÑ‰∫íËÅîÁΩë„Äå‰º¥‰æ£„ÄçÂêóÔºü‰Ω†ÂèàÁúüÁöÑ‰ºö‰ΩøÁî®ÂÆÉ‰ª¨ÂêóÔºüÂ∏åÊúõÈÄöËøáËøôÁØáÂ∞èÊñáÁ´†ÔºåÂ∏¶È¢ÜÂ±èÂπïÂâçÁöÑ‰Ω†‰ª¨ÂØπÁõÆÂâç‰∏ªÊµÅÊêúÁ¥¢ÂºïÊìéÁöÑÂü∫Êú¨ÂéüÁêÜÂΩ¢ÊàêÂü∫Êú¨ËÆ§Áü•ÔºåÂπ∂Âú®Ê≠§ÊâøËØ∫‰∏ç‰ºöÊ∂âÂèäËøáÂ§ö‰∏ì‰∏öÁü•ËØÜÔºàÊØïÁ´üÊàë‰πü‰∏çÂ§™ÊáÇ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ÔºâÔºåÊõ¥ÈáçË¶ÅÁöÑÊòØÔºåÂ∏åÊúõÁî®ÊàëÁöÑ‰∏ÄÁÇπÁÇπÁªèÈ™åÂíåËÆ§Áü•ÔºåÂ∏ÆÂä©Â§ßÂÆ∂Â≠¶‰ºöÊõ¥Â•Ω‰ΩøÁî®ÊêúÁ¥¢ÂºïÊìéËøõË°åÂêÑÁßçÂÜÖÂÆπÁöÑÊêúÁ¥¢„ÄÇ ÊêúÁ¥¢ÂºïÊìéÁöÑÂü∫Êú¨ÂéüÁêÜ ÔºàÊ≥®ÊÑèÔºöËøôÈáåÊâÄËØ¥ÊêúÁ¥¢ÂºïÊìéÊòØÊåáÁã≠‰πâ‰∏äÁöÑÊêúÁ¥¢Â∑•ÂÖ∑Ôºå‰æãÂ¶ÇË∞∑Ê≠å„ÄÅÁôæÂ∫¶„ÄÅÂæÆËΩØÂøÖÂ∫îÁ≠âÔºåÂπ∂ÈùûÂπø‰πâÊêúÁ¥¢ÂºïÊìéÔºåÂ¶Ç‰∏ìÈó®ÊêúÁ¥¢ÁâπÂÆöÁ±ªÂûãÊñá‰ª∂ÁöÑÊêúÁ¥¢ÂºïÊìéÔºåÊàñÊòØÂêÑÂ§ßÂ∫îÁî®ÂÜÖÈÉ®Ê£ÄÁ¥¢ÂÜÖÂÆπÂ∏ñÂ≠êÁöÑÊêúÁ¥¢ÂäüËÉΩÔºå‰ªÖÂØπÁã≠‰πâÊêúÁ¥¢ÂºïÊìéÁöÑÂü∫Êú¨ÂéüÁêÜËøõË°åÂèôËø∞„ÄÇÔºâ ÂÖàÁúãÂÆö‰πâÔºåÊêúÁ¥¢ÂºïÊìéÊòØÊåáÊ†πÊçÆ‰∏ÄÂÆöÁöÑÁ≠ñÁï•ÔºåËøêÁî®ÁâπÂÆöÁöÑËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫Á®ãÂ∫èÊêúÈõÜ‰∫íËÅîÁΩë‰∏äÁöÑ‰ø°ÊÅØÔºåÂπ∂ÂØπÊâÄÊêúÈõÜÂà∞ÁöÑ‰ø°ÊÅØËøõË°åÁªÑÁªáÂíåÂ§ÑÁêÜÔºå‰∏∫Áî®Êà∑Êèê‰æõÊ£ÄÁ¥¢ÊúçÂä°ÁöÑÁ≥ªÁªü„ÄÇ‰ªéÂÆö‰πâ‰∏äÊù•ÁúãÔºåÊêúÁ¥¢ÂºïÊìéÁöÑÂäüËÉΩÂÆûÁé∞‰∏ªË¶ÅÁªèÂéÜ‰ª•‰∏ã‰∏â‰∏™Ê≠•È™§Ôºö 1.¬†‰ªé‰∫íËÅîÁΩë‰∏äËé∑Âèñ‰ø°ÊÅØ„ÄÇÊêúÁ¥¢ÂºïÊìé‰∏ªË¶ÅÈÄöËøáÁâπÂÆöËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫Á®ãÂ∫è‚Äî‚ÄîËúòËõõÁ≥ªÁªüÁ®ãÂ∫èÔºà‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØ‰∫∫‰ª¨ÈÄöÂ∏∏ÊâÄËØ¥ÁöÑÁà¨Ëô´ÔºâÂú®‰∫íËÅîÁΩëËÅîÈÄöÁöÑÂêÑÂ§ßÊúçÂä°Âô®‰∏≠Áà¨ÂèñÁΩëÈ°µÔºåÂπ∂Ê≤øÁùÄÂêÑÁßçÁΩëÈ°µ‰∏≠ÁöÑÊâÄÊúâURLÁà¨Âà∞ÂÖ∂‰ªñÁΩëÈ°µÔºå‰∏çÊñ≠Âª∂‰º∏Áà¨ÂèñÁöÑ„ÄåËß¶Ëßí„ÄçÔºåÂπ∂ÊääÊâÄÊúâÁà¨Âà∞ÁöÑÁΩëÈ°µÊî∂ÈõÜÂõûÊù•„ÄÇ 2.¬†ÂØπÊâÄÊêúÈõÜÂà∞ÁöÑ‰ø°ÊÅØËøõË°åÁªÑÁªáÂ§ÑÁêÜÂπ∂Âª∫Á´ãÁ¥¢ÂºïÊï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ì„ÄÇÁî±ÁâπÂÆöÂàÜÊûêÁ®ãÂ∫èÂØπÊêúÈõÜÂà∞ÁöÑÁΩëÈ°µËøõË°åÂàÜÊûêÔºåÊèêÂèñÁΩëÈ°µ‰∏äÁöÑÁõ∏ÂÖ≥‰ø°ÊÅØÔºàÂåÖÊã¨URL„ÄÅÁΩëÈ°µÂÜÖÂÆπÂèäÂÖ∂ÂÖ≥ÈîÆËØç„ÄÅ‰∏éÂÖ∂‰ªñÁΩëÈ°µÁöÑÂÖ≥Á≥ªÁ≠âÔºâÔºåÂπ∂Ê†πÊçÆ‰∏ÄÂÆöÁöÑÁõ∏ÂÖ≥Â∫¶ÁÆóÊ≥ïËøõË°åËÆ°ÁÆóÔºåÂæóÂà∞ÁΩëÈ°µ‰∏éÁâπÂÆöÂÖ≥ÈîÆËØçÁöÑÁõ∏ÂÖ≥Â∫¶ÔºåÂπ∂‰æùÊçÆÁõ∏ÂÖ≥Â∫¶ËøõË°åÊéíÂ∫èÂêéÂª∫Á´ãÁ¥¢ÂºïÊï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ì„ÄÇËøôÈáåÁöÑÁõ∏ÂÖ≥Â∫¶ÂíåÊéíÂ∫è‰æøÊòØ‰Ω†Âú®Êüê‰∏™ÊêúÁ¥¢ÂºïÊìéÊêúÁ¥¢ÂÜÖÂÆπÊó∂ÂëàÁé∞Âá∫ÁöÑÁ≠îÊ°àÊéíÂàó‰æùÊçÆÔºå‰∏çÂêåÊêúÁ¥¢ÂºïÊìé‰æùÊçÆ‰∏çÂêåÁöÑÊåáÊ†áÂæóÂá∫ÁöÑÂÜÖÂÆπÈ°∫Â∫è‰πü‰∏çÁõ∏ÂêåÔºå‰æãÂ¶ÇÊüêÂ∫¶Ââç‰∫õÂπ¥Ë¢´ÊõùÂá∫ÁöÑÂπøÂëäÂïÜÂèØÂá∫Èí±Ë¥≠‰π∞ÁâπÂÆöÊéíÂ∫èÔºåÂπøÂèóÁΩëÂèãÊä®Âáª„ÄÇÂõ†Ê≠§ÔºåÊâÄÂëàÁé∞ÊêúÁ¥¢ÂÜÖÂÆπÁöÑÊéíÂ∫è‰πüÊòØ‚Ä¶  ( 2 min )
    ÊâãÊääÊâãÂ∏¶‰Ω†Ë£ÖË£±‰∏ÄÈÉ®ÊóßÊâãÊú∫
    ‰∏çÁü•ÈÅì‰ªé‰ªÄ‰πàÊó∂ÂÄôÂºÄÂßãÔºåÊãÜËß£Âπ∂Ë£ÖË£±Â∫üÂºÉÁöÑÁîµÂ≠ê‰∫ßÂìÅÂºÄÂßãÊµÅË°åËµ∑Êù•ÔºåÁîöËá≥‰∏Ä‰∫õÂéÇÂïÜ‰πü‰∏ãÂú∫Êèê‰æõ‰∫ÜÂÆòÊñπÁöÑË£ÖË£±ÊúçÂä°„ÄÇ Áúã‰∫Ü‰∏ãÁΩë‰∏äÂçñÁöÑÊ®°ÁâàÊúâÁÇπÂçÉÁØá‰∏ÄÂæãÔºåËÄå‰∏î‰ª∑Ê†º‰πü‰∏ç‰æøÂÆú„ÄÇÁúã‰∫ÜÂá†ÂÆ∂Â∫óÈì∫ÁöÑ‰ªãÁªçÂêéÔºåÂèëÁé∞ÂÖ∂ÂÆûÂ∑•Â∫èÂπ∂‰∏çÂ§çÊùÇÔºåÂ∞±ÊâìÁÆóËá™Â∑±ËØï‰∏Ä‰∏ã„ÄÇÂºÄÂ§¥ÂÖàÁªôÂ§ßÂÆ∂ÂàÜ‰∫´‰∏Ä‰∏ãÊàëÁöÑË£ÖË£±ÊàêÊûúÔºö ‰∏™‰∫∫ËøòÊòØÊØîËæÉÊª°ÊÑèÁöÑ„ÄÇÁõ∏Ê°ÜÊòØA4Á∫∏ÁöÑÂ∞∫ÂØ∏ÔºåÊï¥‰ΩìËøòÊòØÊØîËæÉÁ¥ßÂáëÁöÑÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫ËßâÂæóÂ§™Â§ß‰∫ÜÊúâÁÇπÂç†Âú∞ÊñπÔºåÁº∫ÁÇπÂ∞±ÊòØÂèÇÊï∞‰∏çËÉΩÂÜôÂæóÂ§™Â§öÔºå‰∏Ä‰∫õÂ∞èÁöÑÈõ∂‰ª∂Â∞±Êîæ‰∏ç‰∏ã‰∫ÜÔºåÂ§ßÂÆ∂Â¶ÇÊûúÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÊääÂÖ®ÈÉ®Èõ∂‰ª∂ÈÉΩÂ±ïÁ§∫Âá∫Êù•ÁöÑËØùÔºåÁõ∏Ê°ÜÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄâÊã©Â§ß‰∏ÄÁÇπÁöÑ„ÄÇ ÊâÄÈúÄÁ¥†Êùê&‰ª∑Ê†ºÔºö ÂÆúÂÆ∂Áõ∏Ê°ÜÔºà39ÂÖÉÔºâ ÈìúÁâàÁ∫∏Ôºà4ÂÖÉÔºâ ÁÉ≠ÁÜîËÉ∂ÔºàÂ∑≤ÊúâÁöÑÔºâ ÂèåÈù¢ËÉ∂ÔºàÂ∑≤ÊúâÁöÑÔºâ ÊâãÊú∫ÊãÜÊú∫Â∑•ÂÖ∑ÔºàÂ∑≤ÊúâÁöÑÔºâ ÊóßÊâãÊú∫ÔºàÂ∑≤ÊúâÁöÑÔºâ Âõ†‰∏∫‰∏Ä‰∫õÊùêÊñôÊòØ‰πãÂâçÂ∞±ÊúâÁöÑÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•Êï¥‰ΩìËä±Ë¥πÊòØ40Â§öÂÖÉÔºåÂ§ßÂ§¥ÈÉΩÂú®ÂÆúÂÆ∂ÁöÑÁõ∏Ê°Ü‰∏ä‰∫ÜÔºåÁΩë‰∏äÂ∫îËØ•ËÉΩÂ§ü‰π∞Âà∞ÂêåÂ∞∫ÂØ∏Êõ¥‰æøÂÆúÁöÑ„ÄÇ‰∏ãÈù¢Â∞±ÂàÜ‰∫´‰∏Ä‰∏ãÂÖ∑‰ΩìÁöÑÊ≠•È™§„ÄÇ Á¨¨‰∏ÄÊ≠•ÔºöÊãÜÊâãÊú∫„ÄÅÈõ∂‰ª∂ÂΩíÁ±ª ÊêúÁ¥¢ÊâãÊú∫ÂûãÂè∑+ÊãÜÊú∫ÊïôÁ®ãÔºåÂ∞±ÂèØ‰ª•ÊâæÂà∞ËØ¶ÁªÜÁöÑÊãÜÊú∫Ê≠•È™§„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûúÊ≤°ÊúâÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÁöÑËØùÔºåÁΩë‰∏äÂæà‰æøÂÆúÂ∞±ËÉΩ‰π∞‰∏ÄÂ•óÔºàÂÖ∂ÂÆûËÄÅÊâãÊú∫ÊúÄÈúÄË¶ÅÁöÑÂ∞±ÊòØÊí¨Ê£íÔºâ„ÄÇ ÊãÜËß£ÁöÑËøáÁ®ãÂ§ßÂÆ∂ÂèØ‰ª•ÈáèÂäõËÄåË°åÔºåÊääÈáçË¶ÅÁöÑÈÉ®‰ª∂ÊãÜ‰∏ãÊù•Â∞±Ë°åÔºå‰πü‰∏ç‰∏ÄÂÆöÈùûË¶ÅËøΩÊ±Ç„ÄåËäØÁâáÁ∫ß„ÄçÁöÑÊãÜËß£„ÄÇ ÊãÜËß£‰πãÂêéÂèØ‰ª•ÁÆÄÂçïÊääÈõ∂‰ª∂ÂΩíÁ±ª„ÄÅÁÆÄÂçïÊëÜÊîæ‰∏Ä‰∏ãÔºåÁÆÄÂçïÊûÑÊÄù‰∏Ä‰∏ãËÉåÊôØÂõæÁ∫∏ÁöÑÂ∏ÉÂ±ÄÔºåÁúãÁúãÊúâÊ≤°Êúâ‰ªÄ‰πàÈõ∂‰ª∂ÊòØÂèØ‰ª•ËàçÂºÉÁöÑ„ÄÇ Á¨¨‰∫åÊ≠•ÔºöËÆæËÆ°„ÄÅÊâìÂç∞ËÉåÊôØÂõæÁâá ÂÆâË£ÖÂô®„ÄÇ Ê∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫êÔºöPhoronix ËÄÅÁéãÁÇπËØÑÔºöËøôÂÄíÊòØ‰∏çÈîôÔºåÂÖ∂ÂÆûÈááÁî®ÁΩëÈ°µÂèØ‰ª•ÊúâÊõ¥‰∏∞ÂØåÁöÑË°®Áé∞ÂäõÂíåÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇ  ( 2 min )
    10 Â§ßÂøÖÂ§á Ubuntu Â∫îÁî®ÔºöÂøÖÂ§áÁØá
    Êú¨ÊñáÂàóÂá∫‰∫Ü 2022 Âπ¥ÂèØ‰ª•Áî®‰∫éÊó•Â∏∏Â∑•‰ΩúÁöÑ 10 ‰∏™ Ubuntu ÂøÖÂ§áÂ∫îÁî®„ÄÇ Êàë‰ª¨ÁªèÂ∏∏ÂøòËÆ∞ÔºåÊúâÊàêÂçÉ‰∏ä‰∏áÁöÑ„ÄÅÂèØ‰ª•‰∏éÂêåÁ±ªÂïÜ‰∏ö‰∫ßÂìÅÁõ∏Â™≤ÁæéÁöÑËá™Áî±ÂºÄÊ∫êÂ∫îÁî®„ÄÇÊ≠§Â§ñÔºåËã•‰Ω†ÊòØ Windows Áî®Êà∑ÔºåÂπ∂ËÄÉËôëÂÆåÂÖ®ÊëÜËÑ± Windows Ôºå‰Ω†‰πüÂ∫îËØ•‰∫ãÂÖà‰∫ÜËß£Ê≠§Á±ªÂ∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫è„ÄÇ Âõ†Ê≠§ÔºåÂú®ËøôÁØá‚ÄúÂøÖÂ§áÁöÑ Ubuntu Â∫îÁî®‚ÄùÊñáÁ´†‰∏≠ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨‰∏∫ÊÄ•ÈúÄËøô‰∫õ‰ø°ÊÅØÁöÑ Linux Áî®Êà∑Âàó‰∏æ‰∫Ü 10 Ê¨æÂ∫îÁî®„ÄÇ ËøôÊòØËøô‰∏™Á≥ªÂàóÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∏âÁØáÊñáÁ´†ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ÈîôËøá‰∫Ü‰πãÂâçÁöÑÊñáÁ´†ÔºåÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøá‰ª•‰∏ãÈìæÊé•ÈòÖËØªÔºö Á¨¨‰∏ÄÁØá Á¨¨‰∫åÁØá Guake ‰Ω†ÊòØÂê¶ÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÂú®Â§ÑÁêÜÈáçË¶ÅÂ∑•‰ΩúÊó∂‰ΩøÁî®Âø´Êç∑ÈîÆÊâìÂºÄ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁªàÁ´ØÔºüËøôÊ¨æ‰∏ãÊãâÂºèÁöÑÁªàÁ´ØÁ®ãÂ∫è Guake ËÉΩÂ§üÂ∏Æ‰Ω†ÂÆûÁé∞„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†Ê≠£Âøô‰∫éÂÜôÊñáÁ´†„ÄÅÂâ™ËæëËßÜÈ¢ë„ÄÅÂú®‰Ω†ÊúÄÂñúÊ¨¢ÁöÑ‰ª£Á†ÅÁºñËæëÂô®‰∏≠ÂÜô‰ª£Á†ÅÔºåÂπ∂ÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÂø´ÈÄüÁî®ÁªàÁ´ØÊ£ÄÊü•‰∏Ä‰∫õ‰∏úË•øÂπ∂ËøîÂõûÂà∞Â∑•‰Ωú‰∏≠ÔºåGuake ËÉΩÂ§üÂ∏ÆÂä©‰Ω†„ÄÇÂè™Áî®Êåâ¬†F12¬†ÁªàÁ´ØÂ∞±‰ºöÁ´ãÂç≥Âá∫Áé∞ÔºåÂÜçÊ¨°Êåâ¬†F12¬†ÂÆÉ‰ºöÊ∂àÂ§±Ôºå‰∏çÁî®ÊâìÂºÄÊàñÂÖ≥Èó≠‰∏çÂêåÁöÑÁªàÁ´Ø„ÄÇ Âú® Ubuntu ÊàñÂÖ∂‰ªñÂèëË°åÁâàÔºå‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®‰ª•‰∏ãÂëΩ‰ª§ÂÆâË£Ö„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÈúÄÊõ¥Â§ö‰∏ãËΩΩÈÄâÈ°πÔºåËØ∑ËÆøÈóÆ¬†Ê≠§È°µÈù¢„ÄÇ sudo apt install guake ÊµèËßà‰ª•‰∏ãÈìæÊé•‰∫ÜËß£ Guake ÁöÑÊõ¥Â§ö‰ø°ÊÅØÔºö ‰∏ªÈ°µ Ê∫êÁ†Å Safe Eyes ÁúºÁùõÂæàÂÆùË¥µÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ÊòØÈïøÊó∂Èó¥‰ΩøÁî®Âπ≥ÊùøÊàñÁîµËÑëÁöÑÁî®Êà∑Ôºå‰Ω†Â∫îËØ•‰øùÊä§Â•ΩÁúºÁùõ„ÄÇËøôÈáåÊúâ‰∏ÄÊ¨æÂèØ‰ª•Â∏ÆÂä©‰Ω†‰øùÊä§ÁúºÁùõÁöÑÂ∫îÁî® ‚Äî‚Äî Safe Eyes ÔºåËÉΩÂ§üÂ∏Æ‰Ω†ÂáèÂ∞ëÂπ∂È¢ÑÈò≤Áî®ÁúºËøáÂ∫¶„ÄÇ Safe Eyes ËøôÊ¨æÂ∫îÁî®‰ºöÂú®‰Ω†ÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÊúüÈó¥‰∏∫‰Ω†Êèê‰æõ‚ÄúÈ°∫Êó∂ÈíàËΩ¨Âä®ÁúºÁùõ 10 Áßí‚ÄùÁ≠âÊ¥ªÂä®ÁöÑÂºπÂá∫ÂºèÊåá‰ª§„ÄÇ ÊàëËÆ§‰∏∫ÂÆÉÊòØÊØè‰∏™‰∫∫ÈÉΩÂ∫îËØ•Â∞ùËØï‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑ‰∏ÄÊ¨æ Ubuntu Â∫îÁî®„ÄÇ ÈÄöËøá PPA ÂèØ‰ª•ÂæàÂÆπÊòìÂú® Ubuntu ‰∏äÂÆâË£Ö Safe Eyes „ÄÇ‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•ÊâìÂºÄÁªàÁ´ØÂπ∂‰ΩøÁî®‰ª•‰∏ãÂëΩ‰ª§ÂÆâË£ÖËøôÊ¨æÂ∫îÁî®„ÄÇ sudo add-apt-repository ppa:sl‚Ä¶  ( 3 min )

  • Open

    Why your password is to weak
    Does your password requires at least the following? Must be a minimum of 8 characters Must contain at least 1 number Must contain at least one uppercase character Must contain at least one lowercase character Must contain at least one special character (!@#$%^&*) Research recently showed this password is cracked in 39 minutes! Yes... you took a risk for brain damage in order to come up with a password like this or let your password manager did the job en still it can be cracked so so fast. In 2020 this password was cracked in 8 hours. That's just 12 times slower then what it is now, imagine how fast it will be within the next 2 years from now. Best possible way to come up with a password is according to the Diceware-method https://diceware.dmuth.org/ Experts use this to add randomness to the words your password contains. Every 5 numbers you throw in a row belongs to a word. Repeat this process until you have at least 7 words and create a passphrase: CannonVirtuousMovableUnnerveRectifiedCreasing One problem is this won't be acceptable by our minimal requirements like we said in the beginning. Of course we can add a number and exclamation mark or whatever, but this isn't the best solution. Also this is pretty harshe to ask everyone to do for "just a password". This also depends on what the value is of what you are trying to secure. But since people are lazy, lets come up with a solution that works for everyone. What we can do is higher the least minimal of characters used. If you go from 8 to 12, this means it can be cracked in 3000 years(!) in 2022. Still in 2020 this was 34000 years, so what will it be within the next 2 years? But it is at least takes waaayyyy more time to crack and hopefully a hackers decides to target an easier victim. Source: https://www.hivesystems.io/blog/are-your-passwords-in-the-green?utm_source=tabletext  ( 4 min )
    SUGGESTED FUTURE PLAN FOR STUDENTS AND NEWBIES.
    01. 3 MONTHS: For 3 months learn Online on YOUTUBE HTML CSS PHP AND JAVASCRIPT. OR FLUTTER DART, FIREBASE, SQL AND PYTHON. 02. INTERNSHIP: Apply for an internship in any Software House for NEXT 3 MONTHS And complete your 6 MONTHS IN DEVELOPMENT. 03. AFTER 6 MONTHS: After 6 months apply for a job in any Software House to Complete ONE YEAR OF DEVELOPMENT. 04. NOW SINCE YOU HAVE COMPLETED ONE YEAR IN DEVELOPMENT: Since you have completed One year in Developement you have got a lot of Infromation based on that apply for highly professional and good paying Job or find ONLINE FREELANCING to earn for the next 1 year to complete 2 YEARS OF YOUR EXPERIENCE IN DEVELOPMENT. 05. AFTER 2 YEARS OF PERFECT PROGRAMMING: Start searching about building a Digital Software. Build your own Brand Identity and find any problem to resolver for next 3 years to complete 5 YEARS OF EXPERTISE. 06. FIND STARTUPS: Find startups and Ideas and Invest in them, Collaborate with them and start MAKING MONEY AS A INVESTOR.  ( 4 min )
    Applying AI for Early Dementia Diagnosis and Prediction
    MobiDev would like to acknowledge and give its warmest thanks to the DementiaBank which made this work possible by providing the data set. Mental illnesses and diseases that cause mental symptoms are somewhat difficult to diagnose due to the uneven nature of such symptoms. One such condition is dementia. While it‚Äôs impossible to cure dementia caused by degenerative diseases, early diagnostics help reduce symptom severity with the proper treatment, or slow down illness progression. Moreover, about 23% of dementia causes are believed to be reversible when diagnosed early. Communicative and reasoning problems are some of the earliest indicators used to identify patients at risk of developing dementia. Applying AI for audio and speech processing significantly improves diagnostic opportunity f‚Ä¶  ( 10 min )
    Java Interface and abstract class related interview questions
    Abstract class Can Abstract class have contructor() ? Yes abstarct classses can have constructors. Even if you don't define JVM will create one default constructor for the abstract class. What is the need of constructor in abstract class ? The main purpose of the constructor is to initialize the newly created object. In abstract class, we have an instance variable, abstract methods, and non-abstract methods. We need to initialize the non-abstract methods and instance variables, therefore abstract classes have a constructor How costructors will be called in an abstract method as we can't create object of abstract class ? It's called with the help of costructor chaining i.e. when we create the object of sub-class, constructor of abstract class will also be called. What will happen i‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )
    How to store and update arrays in React useState hook
    You might have come across different use cases where you would want to store an array in the React state and later modify them. In this article, we will see different ways of doing it. Create a react project by running the following command: npx create-react-app react-usestate-array Update the index.css file with the following code for styling the app: body { display: flex; justify-content: center; } .App { display: flex; flex-direction: column; justify-content: center; align-items: center; } ul { padding: 0; } button { margin: 0.5rem; cursor: pointer; } ul li { display: flex; align-items: center; list-style-type: disc; justify-content: space-between; } Update App.js with the following code: import { useState } from "react" function getRandomNumber(max = 10‚Ä¶  ( 10 min )
    Object Mapping and my journey to minimal boiler-plate code
    A long time ago when I was about to finish university and just above junior level programmer, I joined a new company and received their organized, fresh out of the oven, MVP code. The code was written by an Ukrainian developer I have never met, but loved in my heart. It wasn't the first time I saw a layered application, but it was the best of times. Fast forward a couple of years, my partner and I are now managing the R&D team somewhere (not interesting & not important). Like most teams, we are being swamped with feature requests, and other bullshit the management finds "CRITICAL". Our code-base is still quite organized with the layering we know and love but we start noticing some issues (Add dramatic sound...). Every time we need to add a new CRUD entity to the system, even the most basic‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )
    Sending real-time notifications with Socket.io in Node.js
    How do websites work? A user provides a URL to the web browser. The browser sends a request to the web server, asking for resources related to the URL. The server receives the request and sends an HTTP response containing the related files to the web browser. The browser displays the response as web pages to the user. This type of communication is an HTTP connection, suitable for applications where data doesn't change frequently. Have you ever used a forex trading app or visited a sports betting website? You will notice that the data changes almost every minute; these changes are possible with the help of WebSockets. WebSockets create a connection between a client and a server, allowing them to send data both ways; client-server and server-client. Compared to HTTP, WebSockets provide a ‚Ä¶  ( 10 min )
    Funny Hat Day! üëíüé© How to do face detection with your webcam and JavaScript üì∏üß†

We'll use face-api.js and the Media Stream API for that. Don't worry, though. Nothing will be processed in the cloud or anywhere outside your machine, you'll keep your images, and everything happens in your browser. Let's get started! First, we'll need some HTML: A element, a hat, two buttons for starting and stopping the video, and two for selecting a hat and the device. You know, you might have two webcams. <div‚Ä¶  ( 10 min )
    8 things about Records in C# you probably didn't know
    Records are the new data type introduced in 2021 with C# 9 and .NET Core 5. public record Person(string Name, int Id); Records are the third way of defining data types in C#; the other two are class and struct. Since they're a quite new idea in .NET, we should spend some time experimenting with it and trying to understand its possibilities and functionalities. In this article, we will see 8 properties of Records that you should know before using it, to get the best out of this new data type. By default, Records are immutable. This means that, once you've created one instance, you cannot modify any of its fields: var me = new Person("Davide", 1); me.Name = "AnotherMe"; // won't compile! This operation is not legit. Even the compiler complains: Init-only property or indexer 'Person.Name' c‚Ä¶  ( 8 min )

There are three main reasons why we decided to do that step: Community Innovation Transparency So as of today, you can pip install kern-refinery on your machines to download and run our application. Now that we've finished our open-source go-live, we are looking forward to working towards those three goals every day. Our work towards the release was mainly put into - again - three areas: New UI and improved UX Also, we integrated some features that make it easier to play around with the data from a programmatic point of view, such as the record IDE: You can check out those things in our guide. What do you think of the new UI look? Let us know, we're excited about your feedback!     Wavy Backgrounds with CSS & SVG

    JavaScript sort array based on subarray value
    Now that we had a look at finding the min/max from an array of arrays, let's see how we can go a step further and sort all the items based on a sub-array value. To sketch the problem, let's say we have the following array of users. const users = [ ['Nicole', 31], ['Chris', 33], ['Sanne', 1], ['Yaatree', 2], ]; The users' array contains sub-arrays representing a user's first name and age. We can actually use the native sort method to achieve our goal of sorting this array. In its most basic form, you can call if on an array, and it will try to sort them based on the contents. It would look like this: console.log(['b', 'c', 'a'].sort()); // [ 'a', 'b', 'c' ] However, it's a bit more complicated in our case as we have an array of arrays. console.log(users.sort()); // Returns: // [ // [ 'Chris', 33 ], // [ 'Nicole', 31 ], // [ 'Sanne', 1 ], // [ 'Yaatree', 2 ] // ] This is great if we want to sort on the first name, but we want to sort on the age value. This is where the extra powers of the sort method come in. users.sort((a, b) => { // Do something with a and b }); The above example code is the syntax we can use. Since we are sorting on numbers, they even give us a quick option to sort them. users.sort((a, b) => { return a[1] - b[1]; }); // Returns: // [ // [ 'Sanne', 1 ], // [ 'Yaatree', 2 ], // [ 'Nicole', 31 ], // [ 'Chris', 33 ] // ] We can also change the order by switching the a and b comparison around. users.sort((a, b) => { return b[1] - a[1]; }); // Returns: // [ // [ 'Chris', 33 ], // [ 'Nicole', 31 ], // [ 'Yaatree', 2 ], // [ 'Sanne', 1 ] // ] And to top it off, we can write this as sort hand functions to make it super clean. users.sort((a, b) => a[1] - b[1])); And that's it. We learned how to sort an array based on a sub-array value. Thank you for reading my blog. Feel free to subscribe to my email newsletter and connect on Facebook or Twitter  ( 5 min )

[ÊöëÊúüÂÖºËÅå]‰∏≠ÁßëÈô¢Âú®‰∫¨ÊüêÁ†îÁ©∂ÊâÄËØæÈ¢òÁªÑÊãõËÅòÊöëÊúüÂ≠¶ÁîüÂÖºËÅå ÊâìÂºÄÊµèËßàÂô®ÔºàÊé®ËçêÊñ∞ÁâàÊú¨ÁöÑ Chrome „ÄÅEdge ÔºâÂç≥ÂèØ‰ΩøÁî® Èü≥È¢ëÊñá‰ª∂ÂàÜËΩ®ÔºåÊØè‰ΩçÂèÇ‰∏é‰∫∫ÈÉΩÊúâÂÖ∂Áã¨Á´ãÁöÑÈü≥ËΩ®ÔºåÁïôÁªôÂêéÊúüÂâ™ËæëÂÖÖÂàÜÁöÑÊìç‰ΩúÁ©∫Èó¥ Èü≥È¢ëË¥®ÈáèËææÂà∞‰∫Ü 48kHz „ÄÅ16bit Ê∑±Â∫¶Ôºå768kbps ÁöÑÊ∞¥ÂáÜ Èü≥È¢ëÊñá‰ª∂ËæπÂΩïÂà∂ËæπÂêåÊ≠•Ëá≥‰∫ëÂ≠òÂÇ® ÁªìÊùüÂΩïÂà∂ÂêéÂèØÂ∞ÜÈü≥È¢ëÊñá‰ª∂‰∏ãËΩΩÂà∞Êú¨Âú∞ Êõ¥Â§öÊõ¥ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÁöÑ‰ªãÁªçÂèØ‰ª•ÁÇπÂáªËøôÈáåÊü•ÁúãÔºö ‰∏ãÈù¢ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∫õ‰ΩøÁî®Êà™ÂõæÔºö ÁõÆÂâç‰∫ßÂìÅËøòÂ§Ñ‰∫é beta Èò∂ÊÆµÔºåÊ¨¢ËøéÂØπ mono ÊúâÂÖ¥Ë∂£ÁöÑÊúãÂèãÊ≥®ÂÜåËØïÁî®„ÄÇÊ≥®ÂÜåÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÈúÄË¶ÅÈÇÄËØ∑Á†ÅÔºåÊàëÂÖàÊîæÂá†‰∏™Âú®‰∏ãÈù¢Ôºö n47ds4 9c8892 c4mcmt     Êâæ‰∏Ä‰∏™*nix Á≥ªÂàóÁöÑÊñá‰ª∂‰º†ËæìÂ∑•ÂÖ∑
    humbass: ‰πãÂâçÁî®Ëøá‰∏Ä‰∏™Â∑•ÂÖ∑ÔºåÂΩìÊó∂ÊúçÂä°Âô®‰∏äÊòØ Centos 7.5 Ôºå Êú¨Âú∞ÊòØ macOS Ôºå ‰∏§ËæπÂêÑÂÆâË£Ö‰∏Ä‰∏™Â∑•ÂÖ∑ÔºåËÆ∞Âæó macOS ÊòØÈÄöËøá brew ÂÆâË£ÖÁöÑÔºå ‰∏§ËæπÈúÄË¶Å‰∫§Êç¢Êñá‰ª∂ÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÔºåÂè™ÈúÄË¶ÅËæìÂÖ•Á±ª‰ººËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑÂëΩ‰ª§ÔºåÂ∞±‰ºöÂæóÂà∞‰∏Ä‰∏™Â≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤ÂØÜÁ†ÅÔºåÂ∞±ÂÉèËøôÊ†∑Ôºö ``` xxxtool upload /path/to/file your file number is: 123456 ``` ÁÑ∂ÂêéÂú®ÊúçÂä°Âô®ÊâßË°å ``` xxxtool download 123456 ``` ‰∏§‰∏™Êú∫Âô®ÈÉΩ‰∏çÊòØÊúçÂä°Âô®ÔºàÊ≤°ÊúâÂõ∫ÂÆö IP Ôºâ‰πüÊòØÂèØ‰ª•ÁöÑÔºåÁî®Ëøá‰∏ÄÊ¨°ËßâÂæóÊûÅÂ•ΩÔºåÂêçÂ≠óÂ±ÖÁÑ∂ÊêûÂøòËÆ∞‰∫Ü„ÄÇ Âì™‰ΩçÂ∞è‰ºô‰º¥‰πüÁî®ËøáÁ±ª‰ººÁöÑ  ( 2 min )

    chenyu8674: ‰ΩèÂú®Âë®ËæπÁªøÂåñÊØîËæÉÂ•ΩÁöÑ‰∏ÄÊ•ºÔºåÂÆ∂ÈáåÂπ≥ÂùáÊØèÂ§©Âá∫Áé∞‰∏§‰∏âÂè™Êñ∞ËöäÂ≠êÔºå‰∏•ÈáçÂΩ±ÂìçÁù°Áú†Ë¥®Èáè ÊäõÂºÄÈ©±ËöäÈóÆÈ¢òÊú¨Ë∫´ÔºåÁõÆÂâçÊúÄÊÉ≥ÊêûÊ∏ÖÊ•öÁöÑÊòØÂÆÉ‰ª¨ÊÄé‰πàËøõÂ±ãÁöÑ Â∑≤ËøõË°åËøáÁöÑÊéíÊü•Â¶Ç‰∏ãÔºö ËøõÂÖ•Êà∑Èó®Ââç‰ºöÁâπÂà´Ê≥®ÊÑèÂë®Âõ¥ÊúâÊ≤°ÊúâËöäÂ≠êÔºåÊúâÁöÑËØùÊâìÊ≠ª /Ëµ∂Ëµ∞ÂÜçËøõ Á™óÊà∑‰∏∫Êñ≠Ê°•ÈìùÂÜÖÂºÄ+20 ÁõÆÊ†áÂáÜÁ∫±Á™óÔºåÁªèÊ£ÄÊü•Ê≤°ÊúâÂèëÁé∞Á†¥ÊçüÔºåÊºèÊ∞¥Âè£‰πüÈÉΩË¥¥‰∫ÜÁ∫±Á™óË¥¥Áâá ÊäΩÊ≤πÁÉüÊú∫ /ÁáÉÊ∞îÁÉ≠Ê∞¥Âô®ÁÉüÈÅìÈÄöÊà∑Â§ñÔºåÊúâÊ≠¢ÈÄÜÈòÄ Âç´ÁîüÈó¥Êµ¥Èú∏‰∏Ä‰ΩìÊú∫ÈÄöÂÖ¨ÂÖ±È£éÈÅìÔºåÊúâÊ≠¢ÈÄÜÈòÄ ÁõÆÂâçÂêé‰∏§ËÄÖÂ´åÁñëÊúÄÂ§ßÔºåÊÄÄÁñëÊòØÊ≠¢ÈÄÜÈòÄÊú™ÂÆåÂÖ®Èó≠ÂêàÂØºËá¥È£ûËøõÊù•ÁöÑÔºå‰ΩÜÊ≤°ÊúâÈ™åËØÅÊñπÊ≥ï ÊúâÊ≤°ÊúâËÉΩÊèê‰æõÁÇπÂÖ∂‰ªñÊÄùË∑ØÊàñÂª∫ËÆÆÁöÑÔºåÂÖàË∞¢Ëøá  ( 2 min )

vscode.dev „ÄÅgithub.dev ÂíåÊ°åÈù¢Áâà VS Code ‰∏≠Áõ¥Êé•ËøêË°å Python ÔºÅÂÆÉÊúâ‰∏§Â§ß‰∫ÆÁÇπÔºö Âø´ÈÄü‰æøÊç∑Ôºö‰∏çÈúÄË¶ÅÈ¢ùÂ§ñÂÆâË£Ö Python Ëß£ÈáäÂô®ÔºåÁúüÊ≠£ÁöÑ‰∏ÄÈîÆËøêË°åÔºÅ Á´ôÂú®Â∑®‰∫∫ÁöÑËÇ©ËÜÄ‰∏ä Code Runner for Web ÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÂéüÁêÜÊòØÊÄé‰πàÊ†∑ÁöÑÂë¢Ôºü Êúâ‰∏ãÈù¢‰∏â‰ΩçÈáçË¶ÅÁöÑÂ∑®‰∫∫Ôºö WebAssembly/WASM ( https://webassembly.org/) Emscripten ( https://emscripten.org/):   • Open

    How I configure a DHCP server on my personal network
    How I configure a DHCP server on my personal network David Both Mon, 07/18/2022 - 03:00 Register or Login to like Register or Login to like The Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) provides a centralized and automated method for configuring the network attributes of hosts when they connect to the network. The DHCP server assigns IP addresses to hosts, along with configuration information such as DNS servers, the domain name used for DNS searches, the default gateway, an NTP (Network Time Protocol) server, a server from which a network boot can be performed if necessary, and more. DHCP eliminates the need to configure each network host individually. DHCP is also useful for configuring laptops, mobile phones, tablets, and other devices which might connect as unknown guests. This ‚Ä¶  ( 14 min )
    Create a JavaScript API in 6 minutes
    Create a JavaScript API in 6 minutes Jessica Cherry Mon, 07/18/2022 - 03:00 Register or Login to like Register or Login to like This article demonstrates creating a base API with Express and JavaScript. Express is a NodeJS minimalist web framework. This combination allows for minimal effort to get an API up and running at the speed of light. If you have six minutes of free time, you can get this API working to do something useful. Programming and development Red Hat Developers Blog Programming cheat sheets Try for free: Red Hat Learning Subscription eBook: An introduction to programming with Bash Bash shell scripting cheat sheet eBook: Modernizing Enterprise Java Get started with NodeJS What you need for this project is the NodeJS version of your choice. In this example, I use NodeJ‚Ä¶  ( 7 min )
    Monitor your Linux firewall with nftwatch
    Monitor your Linux firewall with nftwatch Kenneth Aaron Mon, 07/18/2022 - 03:00 Register or Login to like Register or Login to like Netfilter tables (nftables) is the default firewall shipped with modern Linux distros. It's available on Fedora and RHEL 8, the latest Debian, and many others. It replaces the older iptables that was bundled in earlier distro releases. It's a powerful and worthy replacement for iptables, and as someone who uses it extensively, I appreciate its power and functionality. One of the features of nftables is the ability to add counters to many elements, such as rules. These are enabled on demand. You need to explicitly ask for it on a per line basis using the "counter" argument. I have them enabled for specific rules in my firewall, which gives me visibility i‚Ä¶  ( 5 min )

  • Open

    Hyundai N‚Äôs ‚Äòrolling labs‚Äô imagine performance EVs that aren‚Äôt so boring
    Image: Hyundai Hyundai‚Äôs attempting to keep car culture alive with its two performance-focused electric vehicle (EV) concepts it calls ‚Äúrolling labs.‚Äù The RN22e features a modified Ioniq 6 body, and the N Vision 74 is modeled after the never-released 1974 Pony Coupe concept ‚Äî but both feature a refreshing sporty design that doesn‚Äôt look like some sort of futuristic pod (or, well... this thing). The two concepts come from Hyundai‚Äôs ‚ÄúN‚Äù sub-brand, which focuses on high-performance vehicles. The N Vision 74 is the most striking of the two, and features a design that draws elements from the 2025 Hyundai N Vision Gran Turismo and the 1974 Pony Coupe concept that was originally designed by the iconic Giorgetto Giugiaro ‚Äî the same man who went on to make the...     Chris Evans still misses his iPhone 6S and its home button
    Chris Evans as Lloyd Hansen in The Gray Man | Image: Paul Abell/Netflix Fans of buttons can count on Captain America for support, as Chris Evans notes that even after a few weeks with a newer phone, he still prefers his old iPhone 6S and its button. The topic came up in an interview with Collider (via iMore) while doing a press tour for Netflix‚Äôs $200 million+, Russo brothers-directed spy flick The Gray Man, which he stars in along with Ryan Gosling. Evans is far from the only person still stuck on the missing button (he and Donald Trump agree on at least one thing), which Apple swapped for a solid circle with taptic engine feedback on the iPhone 7, and eventually dropped entirely from the iPhone X onward.     Elon Musk says we should see Steam running on Teslas soon
    Photo by James Bareham / The Verge Tesla‚Äôs apparently looking to expand its collection of in-car games... by adding Steam. In a reply to a tweet, Tesla CEO Elon Musk said the company‚Äôs ‚Äúmaking progress with Steam integration‚Äù and that we can expect a demo ‚Äúprobably next month.‚Äù Tesla already offers a number of games through the built-in Tesla Arcade, like Cuphead and Sonic the Hedgehog 1, but adding Steam‚Äôs digital storefront could give users access to a whole lot more. We still don‚Äôt know if the integration will go so far as to allow users to make purchases on Steam while sitting in their cars, or if there will be any games Teslas can‚Äôt support.     Lawmakers push FTC to clean up the VPN industry
    Illustration by Alex Castro / The Verge Last week, Congresswoman Anna Eshoo (D-CA) and Senator Ron Wyden (D-OR) wrote a letter urging the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to address deceptive practices in the Virtual Private Network (VPN) industry. Eshoo and Wyden‚Äôs letter comes as people look to hide their digital footprint following the Supreme Court‚Äôs decision to overturn Roe v. Wade. A VPN allows a user to establish an encrypted connection between their device and a private server, making it harder for third parties to access their online activity. With abortion becoming illegal or restricted in several states, more people are looking to conceal their messages and search history, as police can use this information to prosecute someone seeking the procedure. In their letter,... Continue reading‚Ä¶  ( 5 min )
    Google‚Äôs now solely relying on developers to provide accurate app data collection information
    Image: Google Earlier this year, the Google Play Store launched a new data privacy section that relies on developers to disclose the information their apps collect. But as pointed out by Esper senior editor Mishaal Rahman (via Ars Technica), this may mean that Google will no longer display a verified list of permissions it automatically gathers from each app, giving developers full control over what they choose (or don‚Äôt choose) to disclose to users. When Google first announced the new data privacy section last year, the company made it clear that its system would rely on information provided by developers. On a support page, Google states that developers have until July 20th to fill out a data privacy form for their apps, noting developers ‚Äúalone‚Äù... Continue reading‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )

    repeatOnLifecycle + SharedFlow ÈöêËóèÂùëÊéíÊü•‰∏éÊ≤ªÁêÜ
    È¢òËÆ∞ÔºöËøôÊòØ‰∏Ä ‚Äú‰∫îÂçÅÊ≠•Á¨ëÁôæÊ≠•‚Äù ÊïÖ‰∫ã ‚Äî‚Äî repeatOnLifecycle + sharedFlow Êâ¨Ë®ÄÊõø‰ª£ LiveData ‰∫é‰∫ã‰ª∂Âú∫ÊôØÔºåÁªìÊûúÂÖ∂Ëá™Ë∫´‰πü ‚Ä¶ ü§î ËÉåÊôØ ‰∏äÊúü„ÄäGoogle Android Êû∂ÊûÑËÆæËÆ°ÊãÜËß£ÂèäÊîπÂñÑÂª∫ËÆÆ„Äã‰æßÈáçÊãÜËß£ÂÆòÊñπÊû∂ÊûÑ ‚ÄúÈ¢ÜÂüüÂ±Ç‚Äù ËÆæËÆ°ËØØÂå∫ÔºåÂπ∂ÁªôÂá∫ÊîπÂñÑÂª∫ËÆÆ ‚Äî‚Äî ÈÄöËøá MVI-Dispatcher ÊâøÊãÖ Event-HandlerÔºå ÁÑ∂ÊúâÂ∞è‰ºô‰º¥Ë°®Á§∫Ôºå‰∏ç‰ªÖË¶Å MVI-DispatcherÔºåËøòÊÉ≥ÁúãÁúã Kotlin Áâà MVI ÂÆûË∑µ ÊïÖËøôÊúüÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ËÇù‰∏™ MVI-Dispatcher-KTX Á§∫‰æãÈ°πÁõÆËÄåÊù•„ÄÇ È°πÁõÆÁÆÄ‰ªã ‚ÄúÂçïÂêëÊï∞ÊçÆÊµÅ‚Äù ÊòØËøëÂπ¥ÂÖ¨ËÆ§ ‚ÄúÂõæÂΩ¢ÂåñÂÆ¢Êà∑Á´ØÂºÄÂèë‚Äù È¢ÜÂüüÊúÄ‰Ω≥ÂÆûË∑µÔºå MVI-Dispatcher ÊäπÈô§ ‚ÄúÂçïÂêëÊï∞ÊçÆÊµÅ‚Äù Â≠¶‰π†ÊàêÊú¨Ôºå‰ΩøÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÂú®‰∏çÁÜü mutable„ÄÅMVI ÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÔºå‰ªÖÊ†πÊçÆÁÆÄÊòéÊòìÊáÇ input-output ËÆæËÆ°‰∫¶ÂèØËá™Âä®ÂÆûÁé∞ ‚ÄúÂçïÂêëÊï∞ÊçÆÊµÅ‚Äù ÂºÄÂèëÔºå KTX ÁâàÊé•Âè£‰∏é MVI-Dispatcher ‰øùÊåÅ‰∏ÄËá¥ÔºåÂèØÂΩªÂ∫ïÊ∂àÈô§ mutable Ê†∑Êùø‰ª£Á†ÅÔºõÊùúÁªù setValue/emit ËØØÁî®Êª•Áî®Ôºõ‰∏îÂèØÊó†ÁºùÊï¥Ëá≥ Jetpack MVVM È°πÁõÆ‰∏≠„ÄÇ implementation 'com.kunminx.arch:mvi-dispatch-ktx:6.0.0-beta' ‰ª•‰∏ãÊéíÂùëÊµãËØïËä±ÁµÆÔºö SharedFlow ‰πü ‚Äú‰∏¢‚Äù ‰∫ã‰ª∂Ôºü Âêå MVI-DispatcherÔºåKTX ÁâàÂú® sample module Êèê‰æõ‰∏ÄÁ≥ªÂàóÂ∏∏ËßÑ + Êö¥ÂäõÊµãËØïÔºå Êàë‰ª¨‰∫é ComplexRequester ÂÆâÊéí 4 ÁªÑ‰∫ã‰ª∂ÈÄâÈ°πÔºå‰∫ã‰ª∂ 1 ÂèØËΩÆËØ¢ÈÄöÁü•‰∫ã‰ª∂ 4 ÂõûÊé® UIÔºå‰∫ã‰ª∂ 2 Âª∂Ëøü 200 ÊØ´ÁßíÂêéÂèØÂõûÊé® UIÔºå‰∫ã‰ª∂ 3 ÂèØÁõ¥Êé•ÂõûÊé® UIÔºå class ComplexRequester : MviDispatcherKTX() { ¬†override susp‚Ä¶  ( 7 min )

È°πÁõÆ„ÄÇÊúÄÁªàÁõÆÊ†áÊòØÊ£ÄÊµãÂπ∂ÊäµÂæ°‰ªª‰ΩïÊÅ∂ÊÑèÊ¥ªÂä®„ÄÅÊèê‰∫§ÊúâÁº∫Èô∑ÁöÑ‰ª£Á†Å„ÄÅ‰ªãÂÖ•Âπ≤È¢Ñ„ÄÅÈòªÊ≠¢ÂºÄÂèëÔºåÁîöËá≥Êé•ÁÆ°Êï¥‰∏™ÂºÄÊ∫êÈ°πÁõÆ„ÄÇ‰∏∫Ê≠§Á†îÁ©∂‰∫∫ÂëòÂ∞Ü‰ΩøÁî®ÊÉÖÁª™ÂàÜÊûêÁ≠âÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÔºåÊù•ÂàÜÊûêÂºÄÊ∫êÁ§æÂå∫ÂÜÖÁöÑÁ§æ‰∫§‰∫íÂä® Ê≥®ÊÑèÔºöÊúÄ‰Ω≥ÂÅöÊ≥ïÊòØÈÄâÊã©‰∏ÄÁßçËá™Âä®Áª≠ËÆ¢ÊñπÂºèÔºå‰ª•ÂáèËΩª‰Ω†ËÆ∞‰ΩèÁª≠ËÆ¢Êó•ÊúüÊàñÊâãÂä®ÊâßË°åÁõ∏ÂÖ≥Ê≠•È™§ÁöÑÂéãÂäõ„ÄÇ ÊúâÁÇπË∑ëÈ¢ò‰∫ÜÔºåÊûÑÂª∫‰Ω†Ëá™Â∑±ÁöÑ SSL ËØÅ‰π¶ÁöÑÁ∫ØÂºÄÊ∫êÊñπÂºè     ËØ∫Âü∫‰∫öÂãí‰ª§‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂºÄÊ∫ê Linux ÊâãÊú∫È°πÁõÆ ‚ÄúNOTKIA‚Äù ÊîπÂêçÂ≠ó
    Êúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊÉ≥Ë¶Å‰∏∫‰Ω†Â∏¶Êù•‰∏ÄÊ¨æËØ∫Âü∫‰∫öÈ£éÊ†ºÁöÑ Linux ÊâãÊú∫ÁöÑÂºÄÊ∫êÈ°πÁõÆÔºå‰ΩÜËØ∫Âü∫‰∫ö‰ºº‰πéÂπ∂‰∏çÂñúÊ¨¢Ëøô‰∏™È°πÁõÆÁöÑÂêçÂ≠ó„ÄÇ ËøëÊúüÔºå‰∏Ä‰∏™Êó®Âú®ÊâìÈÄ†ÁªèÂÖ∏ËØ∫Âü∫‰∫öÔºàÂ∞èÂûãÔºâÁöÑ ËôΩÁÑ∂ËøôÊ†∑ÂÅöÂèØ‰ª•‰øùÊä§ÂÖ¨Âè∏ÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°Ôºå‰ΩÜËøô‰∫õÂÖ¨Âè∏ÂêëÂú®ÂΩìÂâçÁä∂ÊÄÅ‰∏ãÁîöËá≥ÂØπ‰ªñ‰ª¨ÊûÑ‰∏çÊàêÂ®ÅËÉÅÁöÑÈ°πÁõÆÂèëÈÄÅ‰æµÊùÉÈÄöÁü•ÊòØÊÄé‰πàÂõû‰∫ãÔºü NotkiaÔºöÂºÄÂèë‰∏ÄÊ¨æË¢ñÁèç Linux ÊâãÊú∫ ‰∏çËøáËøòÂæó¬†ÊÑüË∞¢¬†ËØ∫Âü∫‰∫öÁöÑËøô‰∏™‰æµÊùÉÈÄöÁü•ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÊâçËÉΩ‰∫ÜËß£Âà∞Ëøô‰∏™ÊúâË∂£ÁöÑÈ°πÁõÆÔºöÂºÄÂèë‰∏ÄÊ¨æÊª°Ë∂≥Âü∫Êú¨‰ΩøÁî®„ÄÅÊ≥®ÈáçÈöêÁßÅÁöÑÂ∞èÂûã Linux ÊâãÊú∫„ÄÇ ËØ•È°πÁõÆÁöÑÁõÆÊ†áÊòØËÆæËÆ°‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÆåÂÖ®ÈÄÇÂêàËØ∫Âü∫‰∫öÁªèÂÖ∏ÊâãÊú∫Â§ñÂ£≥ÁöÑ PCB„ÄÇ Âà∞ÁõÆÂâç‰∏∫Ê≠¢ÔºåËØ•È°πÁõÆÂ∑≤ÁªèÊîØÊåÅËÆ∏Â§öÁ°¨‰ª∂Áõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑÂäüËÉΩÔºåÂåÖÊã¨ËìùÁâôÂíå Wi-Fi„ÄÇ ËØ•È°πÁõÆ‰∏çÂü∫‰∫éÂÆâÂçìÔºåËÄåÊòØÂü∫‰∫é‰∏ªÁ∫ø Linux ÂÜÖÊ†∏„ÄÇ ‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•Âú®‰ªñ‰ª¨ÁöÑ¬†ÂÆòÊñπÂçöÊñá¬†‰∏≠Ôºå‰∫ÜËß£ÊúâÂÖ≥ËØ•È°πÁõÆÂíåËÆ°Âàí‰∏≠ÁöÑÊâãÊú∫ËßÑÊ†º„ÄÇ ÁõÆÂâçÔºåËØ•È°πÁõÆÊ≠£Âú®Á≠âÂæÖÁ≠πÊ¨æÔºå‰ª•‰æøÂèØ‰ª•ÂçïÁã¨Ë¥≠‰π∞Êó©ÊúüÂéüÂûãÊú∫„ÄÇ ÁÅµÊÑüÊù•Ëá™ËØ∫Âü∫‰∫öÔºåÂπ∂ÂèóÂà∞ËØ∫Âü∫‰∫öÁöÑÂÖ≥Ê≥® ÂóØÔºåËØ•È°πÁõÆÊ∏ÖÊ•öÂú∞Ë°®Êòé‰ªñ‰ª¨ÂèóÂà∞ËØ∫Âü∫‰∫öÁªèÂÖ∏ÊâãÊú∫ÁöÑÂêØÂèëÔºå‰ªñ‰ª¨Âπ∂Ê≤°ÊúâËØïÂõæËØØÂØº‰ªª‰ΩïË¥°ÁåÆËÄÖÂíåÊΩúÂú®ÂÆ¢Êà∑„ÄÇ     Make It Pixel! - Make pixel art from any image
    There are several options out there for generating pixel art from images. However, none has all the things I would like to have at the same time, so I decided to make my own. Cover generated by MakeItPixel from the Mona Lisa by Leonardo Da Vinci A little disclaimer: I have great respect for pixel artists and I know that "pixel art" is not the most proper name for what programs like mine generate. But lacking a better term, and because everyone uses it, I'll do it too, being aware that generated generated pixel art has flaws that any artist could point out and correct. What would I expect from a pixel art generator? Re-scaling of an image to a given resolution. Optional use of fully customizable palettes. Parameterizable color quantization and dithering. Background removal. Optional outlin‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )
    How to ask for help
    This blog was originally published on blog.dhravya.dev Every couple of days, a beginner comes to our programming server, The Coding horizon, and asks for help - That's perfectly OK! Asking for help is natural and is almost necessary for learning. However, you need to HELP OTHERS to help you. So here's some points to keep in mind, I'll try to keep it short and simple. You might like my blog about Learning to code, for beginners if you enjoyed this one. Let's start off with some things that you absolutely should not do. Many people don't know how to frame their questions very well, so they ask others to join a voice call. Please keep in mind that people that are willing to help you have a life, and they might not be in the situation to join a voice call, or even if they are, they might not b‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )

    In this video, we will learn building COVID19 Tracker Application with Visualization using JavaScript and Mapbox.     How to Analyze Prometheus Alertmanager Alerts Using S3, Athena and CloudFormation

    My Favorite Django ü¶Ñ Template Filters
    üñê Hello Guys! If you want to show the date-time-field of a django model in human familiar term you can use this filter like this: {{ field_date|timesince }} and it will return you the time like 2 days ago format If you want to show the text of a field of a django model as you write in the form (with spaces, and tabs) you could use this filter in template like this: {{ value|linebreaks }} If you want to display the first n words of a django model field in the template you can use this filter. For example if you want to show the first two words of the text you can use the filter like this: {{ text|truncatewords:2 }} and the output will be like Hello Python ... If you want to make an url active of the text of a django model field you can use this template filter like this: {{ text|urlize }} If you want to show the number of words of a django model field in the template you can use this filter like this: {{ text|wordcount }} and it will return the number of the words in the template If you want to show the text of a django model field in Title Case you can use this template filter like this: {{ text|title }} You can use |upper and |lower for respectively UPPER CASE and lower case. üëçThank you for reading my post!  ( 4 min )
    Dear Only Dark Mode Users ! FEAT : Light Mode üîÜ
    There ever been the time where you went deep in to the monitor screen just to concentrate on some code ? There ever been the time where you minify your eyes because the text you are seeing is not clearly visible ? I used only dark mode till today as I was struggling coding in my bright environment. I leaned in to the monitor eventhough the brightness was full. If you're comfortable reading code in light mode in your current environment then thats light mode is for you. As I always work in a well lit environment the light mode really helps see the code sharply. Just like üìù paper and ink. Its not just coding but on other places too! I felt more comfortable seeing in light mode in environment. These preferences are going to change as the day progress. So ultimately if you are doing a lot of coding in the low light, dark mode is best. If you are doing in day time I prefer light mode ( atleast for me ). I do both. There never been one preference is better than other. Thats why its called preferences! Thanks & Cheers! Peace üïä  ( 4 min )
    JavaScript find min/max from array of objects
    In the previous article, we looked at finding the min/max from an array of arrays. Let's see how we can do the same with an array of objects. Our array will look like this: const users = [ { name: 'Nicole', age: 31 }, { name: 'Chris', age: 33 }, { name: 'Yaatree', age: 2 }, { name: 'Sanne', age: 29 }, ]; With this array, we want to find the highest and the lowest age users. Let's see how we can achieve that. We'll use the reduce method to extract one item from the array. The cool thing about the reduce is that the initial value is optional, so that we can omit it for now. const highest = users.reduce((previous, current) => { return current.age > previous.age ? current : previous; }); console.log('highest', highest); // { name: 'Chris', age: 33 } Within this reduce method, we l‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )
    7 Tips for Clean React TypeScript Code you Must Know üßπ‚ú®
    Clean code isn't code that just works. It refers to neatly organized code which is easy to read, simple to understand and a piece of cake to maintain. Let's take a look at some of the best practices for clean code in React, which can take the ease of maintaining your code to the moon! üöÄüåï Quite often while using TypeScript a lot of people skip out on providing explicit types for values, thus missing out on the true benefit TypeScript has to offer. Often these can be seen in code-base: Bad Example 01: const Component = ({ children }: any) => { // ... }; Bad Example 02: const Component = ({ children }: object) => { // ... }; Instead using a properly defined interface would make your life so much easier, with the editor providing you accurate suggestions. Good Example: import { ReactNo‚Ä¶  ( 8 min )
    How important is math in programming?
    A frequently asked question is How important is math in programming? In this blog post, we will dive into math in programming. How important is math in programming? What math do you need in your day-to-day work as a programmer? At the end of this post, you should have a clear picture of how important math is in programming. I'm Jelle, I was a backend developer for several years. The last class I took in math was in high school at age 16. The last topic we touched on was the Pythagorean theorem at the Dutch VMBO level (general education development for Americans). Did my lack of math skills give me any issues in my developer career? One of the first remarks I got when I told non-programmer people that I was a developer is "you must be good at math". It is a common misconception that if you ‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )

    Flet, Áî® Python ÂÜô flutter, ‰∏Ä‰∏™ electron ÁöÑ‰ª£ÊõøÂìÅ
    hxse: https://github.com/flet-dev/flet import flet from flet import IconButton, Page, Row, TextField, icons def main(page: Page): page.title = "Flet counter example" page.vertical_alignment = "center" txt_number = TextField(value="0", text_align="right", width=100) def minus_click(e): txt_number.value = int(txt_number.value) - 1 page.update() def plus_click(e): txt_number.value = int(txt_number.value) + 1 page.update() page.add( Row( [ IconButton(icons.REMOVE, on_click=minus_click), txt_number, IconButton(icons.ADD, on_click=plus_click), ], alignment="center", ) ) flet.app(target=main) Â§ßÂÆ∂ËßâÂæóÊÄé‰πàÊ†∑  ( 2 min )

    Today I learned Amazon will recycle small electronics for free
    Illustration by Alex Castro / The Verge If you have a flip phone that you haven‚Äôt used in over a decade, or maybe even a broken tablet, Amazon will pay for a shipping label that you can use to send it in to get recycled. Apparently, this recycling program has been a thing for a while now, but several of us at The Verge never even knew about it until we saw this tweet from journalist Dave Zatz, and thought it might be a good idea to spread the word. Amazon‚Äôs recycling program lets you ship your small electronics for free from any UPS dropoff point (you just have to provide the packaging). Amazon then transfers the devices it receives to a licensed recycling facility, and notes that it will remove or destroy any ‚Äúidentifying marks or personal information‚Äù during the process....     Image: Intel Intel‚Äôs tempering expectations for its upcoming Arc A750 Limited Edition GPU. Before we dive in, it‚Äôs important to note that the A750 is supposed to be one of Intel‚Äôs top-of-the-line GPUs, as indicated by the ‚Äú7‚Äù at the front of its name. Intel‚Äôs naming conventions have the Arc 5 and Arc 3 sitting below the Arc 7, which are supposed to offer midrange and entry-level performance, respectively.     How to change your Apple ID password
    How to change your Apple ID password in three different ways. | Image: Apple Your Apple ID is your key to using the integrated services of Apple‚Äôs ecosystem, including the App Store, iCloud, iMessage, FaceTime, and Apple Music. You also need one to set up any new Apple device. As with any password, if you think it may have been compromised, you should change it immediately. It‚Äôs also a good idea to change it every few months to help keep it extra secure. When you do choose a new password, you‚Äôll need to think of one that‚Äôs at least eight characters long and uses at least one number, one uppercase letter, and one lowercase letter.     Democratic lawmakers ask federal agencies to crack down on crypto mining
    Workers install a new row of Bitcoin mining machines at the Whinstone US Bitcoin mining facility in Rockdale, Texas, on October 9, 2021. | Photo by MARK FELIX/AFP /AFP via Getty Images On Friday, Elizabeth Warren and other Democratic members of Congress sent a letter to two federal regulators, urging them to take action on the explosion of Bitcoin mining in the US. Sent to the heads of the Environmental Protection Agency and Department of Energy, the letter was spurred by preliminary investigation from lawmakers, which found that just a handful of cryptominers use an enormous amount of energy. In response, the lawmakers ask the agencies to require that crypto-mining companies share data on their energy use and emissions. Seven of the biggest crypto-mining companies in the US have the collective capacity to use over 1 gigawatt of electricity, according to the letter. That‚Äôs the equivalent of two standard coal plants... Continue reading‚Ä¶  ( 7 min )

    ‰∏Ä„ÄÅANRÊ¶ÇËø∞ ANR(Application Not responding)ÊòØÊåáÂ∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫èÊú™ÂìçÂ∫îÔºåAndroidÁ≥ªÁªüÂØπ‰∫é‰∏Ä‰∫õ‰∫ã‰ª∂ÈúÄË¶ÅÂú®‰∏ÄÂÆöÁöÑÊó∂Èó¥ËåÉÂõ¥ÂÜÖÂÆåÊàêÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúË∂ÖËøáÈ¢ÑÂÆöÊó∂Èó¥ËÉΩÊú™ËÉΩÂæóÂà∞ÊúâÊïàÂìçÂ∫îÊàñËÄÖÂìçÂ∫îÊó∂Èó¥ËøáÈïøÔºåÈÉΩ‰ºöÈÄ†ÊàêANR„ÄÇ 1.1„ÄÅAnrÁöÑËß¶ÂèëÊó∂Êú∫ anrÁöÑËß¶ÂèëÊó∂Êú∫ÊúâÂæàÂ§öÁßçÔºåÂü∫Êú¨ÂàÜ‰∏∫‰ª•‰∏ãÂá†ÁÇπÔºö ËæìÂÖ•‰∫ã‰ª∂Ôºö5sÂÜÖÊó†ÂìçÂ∫îÔºåÂ¶ÇÂ±èÂπïËß¶Á¢∞‰∫ã‰ª∂Ôºõ ÂπøÊí≠ÔºöÊâßË°åÂâçÂè∞ÂπøÊí≠ÔºàBroadcastReceiverÔºâÁöÑonReceive()ÊñπÊ≥ïÊó∂10sÊ≤°ÊúâÂ§ÑÁêÜÂÆåÊàêÔºåÂêéÂè∞ÂπøÊí≠ÁöÑË∂ÖÊó∂Êó∂Èó¥‰∏∫60sÔºõ ServiceÔºöÂâçÂè∞Service20sÂÜÖÊ≤°ÊúâÊâßË°åÂÆåÊØïÔºõÂêéÂè∞Service200sÂÜÖÊ≤°ÊúâÊâßË°åÂÆåÊØïÔºõ ContentProviderÔºö10sÂÜÖContentProviderÁöÑpublishÊú™ÊâßË°åÂÆåÔºõ ‰ªé‰∏äÈù¢4ÁÇπÊù•ÁúãÔºåÊØè‰∏ÄÁßçËß¶ÂèëÁöÑÊó∂Êú∫ÈÉΩÊòØÂú®ËßÑÂÆöÁöÑÊó∂Èó¥ÂÜÖÔºåÁúã‰Ω†Ê∂à‰∏çÊ∂àË¥πÂæóÂÆåËá™Ë∫´ÁöÑ‰∫ã‰ª∂ÔºåËÄåÊú¨ÊñáÊâÄÊé¢ËÆ®ÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢òÂ∞±ÊòØÔºåËøô‰∫õÊó∂Èó¥ÊòØÁî±Ë∞ÅÊù•Âà∂ÂÆöÔºåÂπ∂‰∏îAnrÁöÑÊ†∏ÂøÉÁÇπÂú®Âì™Èáå„ÄÇ ‰∫å„ÄÅServiceÁöÑANR ÂâçÂè∞Service20sÂÜÖÊ≤°ÊúâÊâßË°åÂÆåÊØïÔºåÂêéÂè∞Service200sÂÜÖÊ≤°ÊúâÊâßË°åÂÆåÊØïÔºåÂ∞±‰ºöËß¶ÂèëANR„ÄÇ ÂºÄÂêØserviceÊúâ‰∏§ÁßçÊñπÂºèÔºå‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊòØstartService‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊòØbindServiceÔºåÊú¨Êñá‰ªéstartServiceÂºÄÂßãÂàÜÊûêÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÂèØ‰ª•ÂÖàÁúãÁúãserviceÁöÑÂêØÂä®ÊµÅÁ®ã„ÄÇ ÁÆÄÂçïÊ¶ÇÊã¨ÔºåAMSÂºÄÂêØ‰∫ÜserviceÊúçÂä°Ôºå‰º†ÈÄíÂà∞ActiveServicesÔºåActiveServicesÊòØÂçèÂä©AMSÂÆåÊàêÂêØÂä®„ÄÅÁªëÂÆöÁ≠âÈÄªËæëÊìç‰ΩúÔºåÂú®ActiveServiceÁöÑrealStartServiceLockedÊñπÊ≥ï‰∏≠ÂàõÂª∫‰∫ÜserviceÂØπË±°ÔºåÂºÄÂêØ‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™serviceÁöÑonCreate()„ÄÇ serviceÁöÑANRÂú®‰∫éÊó∂Èó¥ÁöÑÊéßÂà∂ÔºåÈÇ£ÂºÄÂßãËÆ°Êó∂ÁöÑÈÄªËæëÊÄé‰πàÁúãÔºü 2.1„ÄÅËÆ°Êó∂ÂºÄÂßã ‰ªéÂêØÂä®serviceÁöÑÊµÅÁ®ã‰∏≠ÂèëÁé∞ÔºåserviceÂêØÂä®ËÆ°Êó∂ÁöÑÈÄªËæëÊòØ‰ªéActiveServi‚Ä¶  ( 8 min )
    KotlinÂçèÁ®ã-ÂçèÁ®ãÁöÑÊó•Â∏∏ËøõÈò∂‰ΩøÁî®
    theme: juejin highlight: a11y-dark KotlinÂçèÁ®ã-ÂçèÁ®ãÁöÑÂ∏∏ËßÅËøõÈò∂‰ΩøÁî® KotlinÂçèÁ®ãÁ≥ªÂàóÔºö ÂçèÁ®ãÁöÑÂü∫Êú¨‰ΩøÁî® ÂçèÁ®ãÁöÑ‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñáÁêÜËß£ ÂçèÁ®ãÁöÑ‰ΩúÁî®ÂüüÁÆ°ÁêÜ ÂçèÁ®ãÁöÑÂ∏∏ËßÅËøõÈò∂‰ΩøÁî®ÔºàÊú¨ÊñáÔºâ ÈÄöËøá‰πãÂâçÁöÑÊñáÁ´†ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÁêÜËß£ÂçèÁ®ãÁöÑÂêØÂä®ÊñπÂºèÔºåÂàáÊç¢Á∫øÁ®ãÁöÑÊñπÂºèÔºåÊåÇËµ∑ÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåÈòªÂ°û‰∏éÈùûÈòªÂ°ûÁöÑÂå∫Âà´„ÄÇ ÁêÜËß£‰∫ÜÂçèÁ®ãÁöÑ‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñáÔºåË∞ÉÂ∫¶Á∫øÁ®ãÔºåÁÆ°ÁêÜÂçèÁ®ãÁöÑJob,ÂºÇÂ∏∏ÁÆ°ÁêÜÁ≠â„ÄÇ ÁêÜËß£‰∫ÜÂçèÁ®ãÁöÑ‰ΩúÁî®ÂüüÔºåÁà∂Â≠êÂçèÁ®ãÁöÑÊ¶ÇÂøµÔºåGlobalScop„ÄÅMainScope Âíå Android ÁâπÊúâÁöÑ lifecycleScope viewModelScope Á≠â„ÄÇ‰∫ÜËß£‰ªñ‰ª¨ÁöÑÂºÇÂêå‰∏é‰ΩøÁî®ÊñπÊ≥ï„ÄÇ ÈÇ£‰πàÂú®ÂÆûÈôÖÂºÄÂèë‰∏≠ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Â¶Ç‰Ωï‰ΩøÁî®ÂçèÁ®ãÂë¢ÔºüÂèàÊúâÂì™‰∫õÊ≥®ÊÑèÁÇπÂë¢ÔºüÊØîÂ¶ÇÁΩëÁªúËØ∑Ê±ÇÂ¶Ç‰Ωï‰ΩøÁî®‰∏éÂ∞ÅË£ÖÔºåËá™ÂÆö‰πâÂçèÁ®ãËøòÊúâÂì™‰∫õÁî®Ê≥ïÔºåÂçèÁ®ãÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÂπ∂Âèë‰∏éÂä†ÈîÅÁ≠âÁ≠â„ÄÇ Êàë‰ª¨‰∏ÄËµ∑ÂæÄ‰∏ãÁúã„ÄÇ ‰∏Ä„ÄÅÂçèÁ®ã‰∏≠‰ΩøÁî®ÁΩëÁªúËØ∑Ê±Ç‰∏éÂ∞ÅË£Ö ‰∏ÄËà¨Êù•ËØ¥Êàë‰ª¨ÁöÑÁΩëÁªúËØ∑Ê±ÇÂ∫îËØ•ÊòØËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑ private fun doNetWork() { val api = DemoRetrofit.apiService.getNews("1", "2") val exceptionHandler = CoroutineExceptionHandler { coroutineContext, throwable -> YYLogUtils.e(throwable.message ?: "ÁΩëÁªúÈîôËØØ") } MainScope().launch(exceptionHandler) { val work = async(Dispatchers.IO) { api.execute() //ÂêåÊ≠•ËØ∑Ê±Ç } //‚Ä¶  ( 9 min )
    ‰Ω†ÁúüÁöÑÊï¢ËêΩÂú∞FlutterÊ°åÈù¢Á´ØÂêóÔºü
    Â¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ÊÉ≥Áî®FlutterÊäÄÊúØÂú®Ê°åÈù¢Á´ØËêΩÂú∞Ôºå‰ªéÊäÄÊúØ‰∏äÊù•ËÆ≤Ôºå‰Ω†ÂøÖÈ°ªËß£ÂÜ≥Ëøô‰∏âÂ§ßÈöæÈ¢òÔºö 1. Â∫îÁî®Á™óÂè£ÂåñÔºåÊèê‰æõÁ™óÂè£Êìç‰ΩúÁöÑËÉΩÂäõÔºõ 2. ÂÆûÁé∞Â§öÁ™óÂè£Ôºõ 3. ÂØπÂ§ñËÆæÁöÑÊîØÊåÅ„ÄÇ ÂâçË®Ä È¶ñÂÖàÁªô‰∏™ÁªìËÆ∫ÔºåFlutterÂú®Ê°åÈù¢Á´ØËêΩÂú∞ÔºåÂÆåÂÖ®ÊòØÂèØË°åÁöÑÔºõ‰ΩÜÁîüÊÄÅËøúÊ≤°ÊúâÂÆòÊñπÊâÄËØ¥ÁöÑÈÇ£‰πàÂÆåÂñÑÔºåÊàëÁîöËá≥ËÆ§‰∏∫ÂÖ∂Ëææ‰∏çÂà∞stableÁöÑÊ†áÂáÜ„ÄÇ ÊúâWindows„ÄÅAndroidÁ≥ªÁªüÔºåÁ≥ªÁªü‰∏çÂêå‰ΩÜUI‰∏ÄËá¥ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Â∞ÜÂú®Ëøô‰∏§‰∏™Âπ≥Âè∞‰∏äËß£ÂÜ≥‰ª•‰∏äÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåÂπ∂ËêΩÂú∞Flutter„ÄÇ ‰∏Ä„ÄÅÁ™óÂè£ÂåñÂíåÁ™óÂè£Êìç‰ΩúÂ≠òÂú®ÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢ò ÂÆûÁé∞Â∫îÁî®Á™óÂè£ÂåñÔºöÂç≥Â∫îÁî®ÊòØÁ™óÂè£ÂåñÂ±ïÁ§∫ÁöÑÔºåÂêåÊó∂ÂèØÊãñÊãΩ„ÄÅÂèØ‰ª•ÁÇπÂáªÂ∫îÁî®Â§ñÁöÑÂú∞Êñπ„ÄÇ Flutter WindowsÊú¨Ë∫´ÊòØÁ™óÂè£ÂåñÁöÑÔºõ ËÄåAndroidÈªòËÆ§ÊòØÂÖ®Â±èÂ∫îÁî®ÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅËÆ©ÊôÆÈÄöÂ∫îÁî®ÊîØÊåÅÁ™óÂè£ÂåñÔºõËã•ÊòØÂ∞èÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÊÄßË¥®ÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®ÔºåËøòÈúÄË¶ÅÊîØÊåÅÂèØÊãñÊãΩ„ÄÅÂèØÁÇπÂáªÂ∫îÁî®Â§ñÁöÑÂú∞ÊñπÔºåËøô‰∫õÂú®Flutter‰∏äÈÉΩÊòØÈúÄË¶ÅÊàë‰ª¨Âú®ÂéüÁîüÂÆûÁé∞ÁöÑ„ÄÇ ÂÆûÁé∞Â∫îÁî®Á™óÂè£ÂåñÂêéÔºå‰∏ÄËà¨ÂºÄÂèëËøáÁ®ã‰∏≠ÔºåËÇØÂÆö‰ºöÈúÄË¶Å‰ª•‰∏ãÂØπÁ™óÂè£ÁöÑÊìç‰ΩúÔºö Â∫îÁî®Á™ó‰ΩìÂúÜÂΩ¢„ÄÅÈò¥ÂΩ±ÊïàÊûúÔºõ ÈÖçÁΩÆÂ∫îÁî®ÂàùÂßãÁöÑÊòæÁ§∫‰ΩçÁΩÆÔºõÔºàÂæàÂ§öÂ∞èÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÂèØËÉΩ‰∏çÊòØÂ±Ö‰∏≠Â±ïÁ§∫Ôºâ ‰ªéÁ™óÂè£Âèò‰∏∫ÂÖ®Â±è„ÄÅ‰ªéÂÖ®Â±èÂèò‰∏∫Á™óÂè£Ôºõ ...... ‰∫å„ÄÅÊîØÊåÅÂ§öÁ™óÂè£ ÁõÆÂâçFlutterÊòØÊòéÁ°Æ‰∏çÊîØÊåÅÂ§öÁ™óÂè£ÁöÑ„ÄÇÂÆòÊñπÂ•ΩÂÉèÂØπÂ§öÁ™óÂè£‰∏çÂ§™ÊÑüÂÖ¥Ë∂£Ôºå‰∏ÄÁõ¥Ê≤°ÊúâÊää‰ºòÂÖàÁ∫ßÊèê‰∏äÊù•ÔºåËøòÊòØÂÅúÁïôÂú®p4Á∫ßÂà´ÔºåÂÖ∑‰ΩìËßÅissue„ÄÇ ‰∏â„ÄÅÁ™óÂè£ÂåñÂÆûÁé∞ÊñπÊ°à 1. WindowsÁ´Ø WindowsÁ´ØFlutterÈªòËÆ§ÊîØÊåÅÁ™óÂè£ÂåñÔºå‰∫§‰∫íÊñπÂºèÂü∫Êú¨Á¨¶Âêà‰π†ÊÉØÔºåÂõ†Ê≠§Êó†ÈúÄÂÜçÂÅöÂºÄÂèë„ÄÇ 2. AndroidÁ´Ø AndroidÊôÆÈÄöÂ∫îÁî®ÂÆûÁé∞Á™óÂè£ÂåñÔºåÊòØÊääÊï¥‰∏™Â∫îÁî®Â±ïÁ§∫ÊàêÁ™óÂè£ÁöÑÊïàÊûúÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØÁÇπÂáªÂ§ñÈÉ®Á™óÂè£Â§ñÁöÑÂú∞ÊñπÂÖ∂ÂÆûÊòØ‰∏çÂìçÂ∫î„ÄÇ Âêå‰∏ÄÊó∂Èó¥Âè™ËÉΩÊòæÁ§∫‰∏Ä‰∏™Â∫îÁî®ËøõÁ®ãÔºåËøôÊòØÂÆâÂçìÁöÑÊú∫Âà∂Ôºå‰πü‰øùËØÅ‰∫ÜÂÖ∂ÂÆâÂÖ®ÊÄß„ÄÇË¶ÅÂÆûÁé∞Á™óÂè£ÂåñÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÊääÂ∫îÁî®ThemeËÆæÁΩÆÊàêDialogÁöÑÊ†∑ÂºèÔºõÂêåÊó∂ËÆæÁΩÆÁ™óÂè£ÂÖ®Â±èÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØËÉåÊôØËâ≤‰∏∫ÈÄèÊòéÔºåËÆæÁΩÆÁÇπÂáªÂ§ñÈÉ®Dialog‰∏çÊ∂àÂ§±ÔºåÂç≥ÂèØÂÆûÁé∞Â∫îÁî®ÁöÑÁ™óÂè£ÂåñÂ±ïÁ§∫„ÄÇ ËÆæÁΩÆ‰∏ªÈ¢ò @drawable‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )
    È´ò‰ªø‰∫¨‰∏úAndroid AppÔºåÈõÜÊàêReact-NativeÁÉ≠Êõ¥ÂäüËÉΩ

Ëá™Áß∞‚ÄúÁªìÂêà‰∫Ü Python„ÄÅAda Âíå Modula Á≠âÊàêÁÜüËØ≠Ë®ÄÁöÑÊàêÂäüÊ¶ÇÂøµ‚ÄùÔºå‰ª•ÂâçÊõæË¢´Áß∞‰∏∫ÂÉè C ‰∏ÄÊ†∑Âø´ÔºåÂèàÂÉè Python ‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÂÖ∑ÊúâË°®Áé∞Âäõ„ÄÅÂÉè Lisp ÁºñÁ®ãËØ≠Ë®Ä‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÂèØÊâ©Â±ï„ÄÇopenSUSE ‰∏ç‰ªÖÂÆ£Â∏É‰∏∫ Nim ËØ≠Ë®ÄÊèê‰æõÊúÄÊñ∞ÁöÑËΩØ‰ª∂ÂåÖÔºåËÄå‰∏îÂØπËøô‰∏™ÈùôÊÄÅÁ±ªÂûã„ÄÅÂëΩ‰ª§ÂºèÁºñÁ®ãËØ≠Ë®ÄÁöÑÊèê‰æõ‰∏ÄÁ∫ßÊîØÊåÅ„ÄÇNim ÁöÑ‰ΩúËÄÖÂèäÁ§æÂå∫ÂØπ openSUSE Êèê‰æõ‰∏ÄÁ∫ßÊîØÊåÅË°®Á§∫Ê¨¢Ê¨£ÈºìËàû„ÄÇ Ê∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫êÔºöPhoronix ËÄÅÁéãÁÇπËØÑÔºöÂæàÂ§öÊñ∞ÂÖ¥ËØ≠Ë®ÄÈÉΩÈõÑÂøÉÂãÉÂãÉÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßçÁºñÁ®ãËØ≠Ë®ÄË¶ÅÊàêÂäüÔºåÁúüÊúâÊó∂ÂÄôÊúâÂæàÂ§ö‰æ•Âπ∏ÁöÑÂú∞Êñπ„ÄÇ Rocky Linux 9.0 ÂèëÂ∏É Rocky Linux 9.0 Âª∫Á´ãÂú® RHEL 9.0 ÁöÑÂü∫Á°Ä‰∏äÔºåÂπ∂ËÆ°ÂàíÊîØÊåÅËøëÂçÅÂπ¥ÔºåÁõ¥Âà∞ 2032 Âπ¥ 5 Êúà„ÄÇÁé∞ÊúâÁöÑRocky Linux 8 Â∞ÜÁªßÁª≠Ë¢´ÊîØÊåÅÂà∞ 2029 Âπ¥ 5 Êúà„ÄÇRocky Linux Ê∏¥ÊúõÊàê‰∏∫ CentOS Stream ‰πãÂâçÁöÑ CentOS„ÄÇÁî±‰∫é‰ΩøÁî®‰∫ÜÁ∫¢Â∏Ω‰ºÅ‰∏ö Linux 9.0 ÁöÑÊ∫ê‰ª£Á†ÅÔºåÂÆÉÁöÑÊâÄÊúâÂäüËÉΩ‰∏é 5 Êúà‰ªΩËææÂà∞ GA ÁöÑÈÇ£‰∏™ RHEL ÂèëË°åÁâàÁõ∏Âêå„ÄÇ Ê∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫êÔºöPhoronix ËÄÅÁéãÁÇπËØÑÔºö‰ªéÁõÆÂâçÁúãËµ∑Êù•ÔºåRocky Linux Âíå Alma Linux ÊòØÊúÄËÇñ‰ºº CentOS ÁöÑÁªßÊâøËÄÖ‰∫Ü„ÄÇ  ( 2 min )
    Áî® ranger Âú® Linux ÁªàÁ´ØÁÆ°ÁêÜ‰Ω†ÁöÑÊñá‰ª∂
    ËØïËØïËøô‰∏™ËΩªÈáèÁ∫ßÁöÑÂºÄÊ∫êÂ∑•ÂÖ∑Ôºå‰∏çÁî®Á¶ªÂºÄÁªàÁ´ØÂ∞±ÂèØ‰ª•È¢ÑËßàÊñá‰ª∂„ÄÇ Êü•Áúã‰Ω†ÁöÑÊñá‰ª∂ÂíåÊñá‰ª∂Â§πÁöÑÊúÄÂü∫Êú¨ÊñπÊ≥ïÊòØ‰ΩøÁî®ÂëΩ‰ª§¬†ls¬†Âíå¬†ll„ÄÇ‰ΩÜÊòØÊúâÊó∂ÂÄôÔºåÊàë‰∏ç‰ªÖÊÉ≥ÁúãÂà∞Êñá‰ª∂ÁöÑÂÖÉÊï∞ÊçÆÔºåËøòÊÉ≥‰∏ÄÁõÆ‰∫ÜÁÑ∂Âú∞ÁúãÂà∞Êñá‰ª∂ÁöÑÂÜÖÂÆπ„ÄÇ‰∏∫Ê≠§ÔºåÊàë‰ΩøÁî® ranger„ÄÇ Â¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ÂñúÊ¨¢Âú®ÊéßÂà∂Âè∞‰∏≠Â∑•‰ΩúÔºåÂπ∂‰ΩøÁî®¬†Vim¬†Êàñ ViÔºåËÄå‰∏î‰Ω†‰∏çÊÉ≥Âõ†‰∏∫‰ªª‰ΩïÂéüÂõ†Á¶ªÂºÄ‰Ω†ÁöÑÁªàÁ´ØÔºåÈÇ£‰πà ranger Â∞±ÊòØ‰Ω†ÊúÄÂ•ΩÁöÑÊñ∞ÊúãÂèã„ÄÇranger ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Á≤æÁÆÄÁöÑÊñá‰ª∂ÁÆ°ÁêÜÂô®ÔºåÂÆÉ‰∏ç‰ªÖÂèØ‰ª•ËÆ©‰Ω†ÊµèËßàÊñá‰ª∂ÔºåËøòÂèØ‰ª•È¢ÑËßàÂÆÉ‰ª¨„ÄÇranger ‰∏é rifle ÊçÜÁªëÂú®‰∏ÄËµ∑Ôºårifle ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Êñá‰ª∂ÊâßË°åÂô®ÔºåÂèØ‰ª•ÊúâÊïàÂú∞ÈÄâÊã©‰∏éÁâπÂÆöÊñá‰ª∂Á±ªÂûãÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑÁ®ãÂ∫è„ÄÇ Âú® Linux ‰∏äÂÆâË£Ö ranger ranger ÂèØ‰ª•Âú® Fedora Êàñ‰ªª‰ΩïÂü∫‰∫é RPM ÁöÑÂèëË°åÁâà‰∏≠ÂÆâË£ÖÔºåÊñπÊ≥ïÊòØËøêË°åÔºö $ sudo dnf install ranger ranger ‰πüÂèØ‰ª•Áî®‰∫é¬†ÂÖ∂‰ªñÂèëË°åÁâàÂíå macOS„ÄÇ Á¨¨‰∏ÄÊ¨°‰ΩøÁî® ranger ‰Ωú‰∏∫‰∏Ä‰∏™Áî®Êà∑Ôºå‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•Âú®‰Ω†ÂñúÊ¨¢ÁöÑÁªàÁ´Ø‰∏äÁÆÄÂçïÂú∞ËæìÂÖ•¬†ranger¬†Êù•ÂêØÂä® ranger„ÄÇÂèØ‰ª•Áî®ÊñπÂêëÈîÆÊµèËßà„ÄÇËøôÂº†Êà™ÂõæÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂæàÂ•ΩÁöÑ‰æãÂ≠êÔºåÊàëÂèØ‰ª•È¢ÑËßàÂ≠òÂÇ®Âú®¬†Kernel-tests¬†‰∏≠ÁöÑ¬†config.example¬†Êñá‰ª∂ÁöÑ‰ª£Á†Å„ÄÇ ÈÄâ‰∏≠‰ªª‰ΩïÊñá‰ª∂Âπ∂Êåâ‰∏ã¬†F4¬†ÈîÆÔºåÂ∞±ÂèØ‰ª•ÊâìÂºÄ‰Ω†ÁöÑÈªòËÆ§ÁºñËæëÂô®ÔºåËÆ©‰Ω†Á´ãÂç≥ÁºñËæëËøô‰∫õÊñá‰ª∂ÔºÅ ÂõæÂÉèÂíåËßÜÈ¢ëÊÄé‰πàÂäûÔºü ‰ΩøÁî®¬†rifle¬†Âíå ranger ÂèØ‰ª•ËÆ©‰Ω†Âø´ÈÄüÊâæÂà∞‰∏éÊüê‰∏ÄÊñá‰ª∂Áõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑÁ®ãÂ∫è„ÄÇÂ∞ÜÈº†Ê†áÊÇ¨ÂÅúÂú®ÂõæÁâá‰∏äÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéËØïÂõæÊâìÂºÄÂÆÉÊòØÈùûÂ∏∏ÁÆÄÂçïÁöÑÔºåÂè™Ë¶ÅÁÇπÂáªÂõûËΩ¶Âç≥ÂèØ„ÄÇ‰∏ãÈù¢ÊòØÂÆÉÁöÑÊ†∑Â≠êÔºö Âú®‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂõæÂÉèÊñá‰ª∂‰∏äÁÇπÂáª¬†i¬†‰ºöÁªôÁî®Êà∑Êèê‰æõÊâÄÊúâÁöÑ EXIF Êï∞ÊçÆ„ÄÇÁÇπÂáª¬†Shift+Enter¬†Â∞ÜÊâìÂºÄËøô‰∏™ PDF Êñá‰ª∂„ÄÇ ÂêåÊ†∑ÁöÑÁªÑÂêàÈîÆÂ∞ÜÂú®Á≥ªÁªüÈªòËÆ§ÁöÑÊîØÊåÅËØ•ÁºñËß£Á†ÅÂô®ÁöÑËßÜÈ¢ëÊí≠ÊîæÂô®‰∏≠ÊâìÂºÄÂπ∂ÂºÄÂßãÊí≠ÊîæËßÜÈ¢ë„ÄÇ‰∏ãÈù¢ÁöÑ‰æãÂ≠êÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ mp4 ËßÜÈ¢ëÔºåÂÆÉÂú®¬†VLC¬†‰∏äÊí≠ÊîæÂæóÂæàÂ•Ω„ÄÇ Êñá‰ª∂Êìç‰Ωú Èô§Èùû Vim Áî®Êà∑Âè¶ÊúâÈÖçÁΩÆÔºåÂê¶Âàô‰∏ãÈù¢ÁöÑÈîÆÁªëÂÆöÂ∑•‰ΩúËâØÂ•Ω„ÄÇ jÔºö‰∏ãÁßª kÔºö‰∏äÁßª h: ÁßªÂä®Âà∞Áà∂ÁõÆÂΩï ggÔºöÁßªÂà∞ÂàóË°®ÁöÑÈ°∂ÈÉ® iÔºöÈ¢ÑËßàÊñá‰ª∂ rÔºöÊâìÂºÄÊñá‰ª∂ zhÔºöÊü•ÁúãÈöêËóèÊñá‰ª∂ cwÔºöÈáçÂëΩÂêçÂΩìÂâçÊñá‰ª∂ yyÔºöÂ§çÂà∂Êñá‰ª∂ ddÔºöÂâ™ÂàáÊñá‰ª∂ ppÔºöÁ≤òË¥¥Êñá‰ª∂ uÔºöÊí§ÈîÄ zÔºöÊîπÂèòËÆæÁΩÆ dDÔºöÂà†Èô§Êñá‰ª∂ ÊéßÂà∂Âè∞ÂëΩ‰ª§ ÊúâÊó∂ÊàëÂú®Ëµ∑ËçâÊñáÁ´†Êó∂ÔºåÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™Êñá‰ª∂Â§πÂåÖÂê´Êüê‰∏™ËΩØ‰ª∂ÁöÑÊà™Âõæ„ÄÇÈÄöËøáÁÇπÂáªÁ©∫Ê†ºÈÄâÊã©ÊàñÊ†áËÆ∞Êñá‰ª∂ÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéËæìÂÖ•¬†:bulkrenameÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Â∏ÆÂä©ÊàëÊääÊâÄÊúâÂ•áÊÄ™ÁöÑÊó∂Èó¥Êà≥ÂèòÊàêÂ¶ÇÔºölorax1„ÄÅlorax2 Á≠âÁ≠â„ÄÇ‰∏ãÈù¢ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™‰æãÂ≠ê„ÄÇ ÂÖ∂‰ªñÊúâÁî®ÁöÑÊéßÂà∂Âè∞ÂëΩ‰ª§ÂåÖÊã¨Ôºö penwithÔºöÁî®‰Ω†ÈÄâÊã©ÁöÑÁ®ãÂ∫èÊâìÂºÄ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈÄâÊã©ÁöÑÊñá‰ª∂ :touch FILENAMEÔºöÂàõÂª∫‰∏Ä‰∏™Êñá‰ª∂ :mkdir FILENAMEÔºöÂàõÂª∫‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁõÆÂΩï :shell ÔºöÂú® shell ‰∏≠ËøêË°å‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂëΩ‰ª§ :deleteÔºöÂà†Èô§Êñá‰ª∂ Âú® tty2/3/4 ‰∏≠ËÉΩÂ∑•‰ΩúÂêóÔºü ‰Ωú‰∏∫‰∏Ä‰∏™‰ªé‰∫ãË¥®Èáè‰øùËØÅÔºàQAÔºâÂ∑•‰ΩúÁöÑ‰∫∫ÔºåÊàëÂèëÁé∞ÊêúÁ¥¢Êó•ÂøóÂíåÈòÖËØªÊó•Âøó‰ªéÊú™Â¶ÇÊ≠§ÁÆÄÂçï„ÄÇÂç≥‰ΩøÊàëÁöÑ Gnome ÊòæÁ§∫ÁÆ°ÁêÜÂô®Â¥©Ê∫É‰∫ÜÔºåÊàë‰πüÂèØ‰ª•ÂàáÊç¢Âà∞ÊàëÁöÑ tty2ÔºåÁî®ÊàëÁöÑÁî®Êà∑ÂêçÂíåÂØÜÁ†ÅÁôªÂΩïÔºåÂπ∂‰ª•Ë∂ÖÁ∫ßÁî®Êà∑ÊùÉÈôêÂêØÂä® rangerÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÊàëÂ∞±ÂèØ‰ª•Â∞ΩÊÉÖÂú∞Êé¢Á¥¢‰∫ÜÔºÅ ranger ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂæàÂ•ΩÁöÑÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Âú®‰∏çÁ¶ªÂºÄÁªàÁ´ØÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÂ§ÑÁêÜÊñá‰ª∂„ÄÇranger ÊòØÁ≤æÁÆÄÁöÑÔºå‰πüÊòØÂèØÂÆöÂà∂ÁöÑÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•‰∏çÂ¶®‰∏ÄËØïÂêßÔºÅ ÂõæÁâáÊù•Ê∫êÔºöÔºàSumantro MukherjeeÔºåCC BY-SA 4.0Ôºâ     Âú® VirtualBox ÂÆâË£Ö Arch Linux ÁöÑÊñ∞ÊâãÊìç‰ΩúÊåáÂçó
    Arch Linux Âú®Ê°åÈù¢ Linux ‰∏ñÁïå‰∏≠ÈùûÂ∏∏ÊµÅË°å„ÄÇÂèóÊ¨¢ËøéÁöÑÂéüÂõ†‰πã‰∏ÄÊòØ¬†ÂÆâË£Ö Arch Linux¬†Êú¨Ë∫´Â∞±ÊòØ‰∏ÄÈ°πÂ§çÊùÇÁöÑ‰ªªÂä°„ÄÇ ÊàëÊ≤°ÊúâÂ§∏Â§ßÂÖ∂ËØç„ÄÇÂÆâË£Ö¬†Ubuntu Êàñ Debian¬†ÊØî Arch Linux ÂÆπÊòìÂæóÂ§öÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫ÂÆòÊñπÊ≤°ÁªôÂêéËÄÖÊèê‰æõÂõæÂΩ¢ÁïåÈù¢ÁöÑÂÆâË£ÖÁ®ãÂ∫è„ÄÇ ËøôÊó∂ËôöÊãüÊú∫Â∞±Ê¥æ‰∏äÁî®Âú∫‰∫Ü„ÄÇ ‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•ÂÖàÂú® VirtualBox ‰∏≠Â∞ùËØïÂÆâË£Ö Arch LinuxÔºåÁúãÁúãÂÆÉÊòØÂê¶ÊòØ‰Ω†ÊÉ≥Âú®ÂÆûÈôÖÁ°¨‰ª∂‰∏äËøêË°åÁöÑÁ≥ªÁªü„ÄÇÈÄöËøáËøôÁßçÊñπÂºèÔºå‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•Âú®‰∏çÂºÑ‰π±ÂΩìÂâçÊìç‰ΩúÁ≥ªÁªüÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ã‰ΩìÈ™å Arch Linux„ÄÇ Âú®Êú¨ÊñáÔºåÊàëÂ∞Ü‰∏ÄÊ≠•‰∏ÄÊ≠•ÊåáÂØº‰Ω†ÂÆåÊàê‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÆûÁî®ÁöÑ Arch Linux ËôöÊãüÊú∫ÁöÑÂÆâË£ÖËøáÁ®ã„ÄÇ Âú® VirtualBox ‰∏äÂÆâË£Ö Arch Linux ÊØ´Êó†ÁñëÈóÆÔºå‰Ω†ÈúÄË¶ÅÂÖà¬†Âú® Linux ‰∏äÂÆâË£Ö VirtualBoxÔºàÊàñÂú® Windows ‰∏äÔºâ„ÄÇÂú® Windows ‰∏äÔºåÂè™ÈúÄËÆøÈóÆ Oracle ÁöÑÁΩëÁ´ôÂπ∂‰∏ãËΩΩ VirtualBox„ÄÇ ‰∏ãËΩΩ VirtualBox Â¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑÊòØ Windows 10 ÊàñÊõ¥È´òÁâàÊú¨ÔºåËØ∑Á°Æ‰øù‰Ω†ÁöÑÁ≥ªÁªüÂ∑≤ÂêØÁî®ËôöÊãüÂåñ„ÄÇ ÂÆåÊàêÂêéÔºå‰Ω†ÈúÄË¶ÅÂà∞¬†Arch Linux ÂÆòÊñπÁΩëÁ´ô¬†‰∏ãËΩΩ ISO Êñá‰ª∂„ÄÇ‰Ω†Â∫îËØ•ÊâæÂà∞¬†‰ΩøÁî® torrent ‰∏ãËΩΩ¬†ÊàñÁõ¥Êé•‰∏ãËΩΩÊñá‰ª∂ÁöÑÈÄâÈ°π„ÄÇ ‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•‰øùÁïô ISO Êñá‰ª∂‰ª•Â§á‰∏çÊó∂‰πãÈúÄÔºåÂÆâË£ÖÊàêÂäüÂêé‰πüÂèØ‰ª•Â∞ÜÂÖ∂Âà†Èô§‰ª•¬†ÈáäÊîæÁ≥ªÁªü‰∏äÁöÑÁ©∫Èó¥„ÄÇ Áé∞Âú®ÔºåËÆ©Êàë‰ª¨ÂºÄÂßãÂú® VirtualBox ‰∏äÂÆâË£Ö Arch Linux Âêß„ÄÇ Á¨¨‰∏ÄÈÉ®ÂàÜ ÂàõÂª∫ËôöÊãüÊú∫ Á¨¨‰∏ÄÊ≠•ÔºöÈ¶ñÂÖàÔºå‰Ω†ÈúÄË¶ÅÂú® VirtualBox ‰∏≠ËÆæÁΩÆ‰∏Ä‰∏ã„ÄÇÂêØÂä® VirtualBox Âπ∂ÂçïÂáª ‚ÄúÊñ∞Âª∫New‚Äù Êù•ÂàõÂª∫‰∏Ä‰∏™ËôöÊãüÊú∫„ÄÇ Ê≥®ÊÑèÔºå‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî® ‚ÄúÂêëÂØºÊ®°Âºèguided mode‚Äù ÁªßÁª≠ÂàõÂª∫ËôöÊãüÊú∫Ôºå‰ΩÜ‰ΩøÁî® ‚Äú‰∏ìÂÆ∂Ê®°Âºèexpert mode‚Äù ÂèØ‰ª•‰∏ÄÁõÆ‰∫ÜÁÑ∂Âú∞Ëé∑ÂæóÊõ¥Â§öÈÄâÈ°π„ÄÇ Âõ†Ê≠§ÔºåÊàëÊé®Ëçê‰ΩøÁî®‚Ä¶  ( 3 min )
    gedit Ê∑±Ëâ≤Ê®°Âºè‰∏ãÈ´ò‰∫ÆÊñáÊú¨‰∏çÂèØËßÅÔºü‰ª•‰∏ãÊòØ‰Ω†ËÉΩÂÅöÁöÑ
    ÊàëÂñúÊ¨¢¬†Âú® Ubuntu ‰∏≠‰ΩøÁî®Ê∑±Ëâ≤Ê®°Âºè„ÄÇÂú®ÊàëÁúãÊù•Ê∑±Ëâ≤Ê®°ÂºèËÉΩÂ§üÁºìËß£ËßÜËßâÁñ≤Âä≥ÔºåËÆ©Á≥ªÁªüÁúãËµ∑Êù•Êõ¥Âä†ÁöÑËµèÂøÉÊÇ¶ÁõÆ„ÄÇ ÊàëÂèëÁé∞‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™¬†gedit¬†ÊñáÊú¨ÁºñËæëÂô®ÁöÑÂ∞èÈ∫ªÁÉ¶ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†Âú®Ê∑±Ëâ≤Ê®°Âºè‰∏ã‰ΩøÁî®ÂÆÉÔºå‰Ω†‰πüËÆ∏‰πü‰ºöÈÅáÂà∞„ÄÇ ÈªòËÆ§ÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ã gedit È´ò‰∫ÆÂΩìÂâçÂÖâÊ†áÊâÄÂú®ÁöÑË°å„ÄÇËøôÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈùûÂ∏∏ÊúâÁî®ÁöÑÂäüËÉΩÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†Âú® Linux Á≥ªÁªü‰∏≠ÂºÄÂêØ‰∫ÜÊ∑±Ëâ≤Ê®°ÂºèÔºåÈÇ£‰πà‰Ω†Â∞Ü‰ºöÊÑüÂà∞ÁóõËã¶„ÄÇ‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàÔºüÂõ†‰∏∫Ë¢´È´ò‰∫ÆÁöÑÊñáÊú¨Â∞Ü‰∏çÂÜçÂèòÂæóÂèØËØª„ÄÇ‰Ω†Ëá™Â∑±ÁúãÂêßÔºö Â¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ÈÄâÊã©ÊñáÊú¨ÔºåÂÆÉÂ∞ÜÂèòÂæóÂèØËØªÔºå‰ΩÜËøôÂπ∂‰∏çÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ËÆ©‰∫∫ÊÑüÂà∞ÊúâÂ§ö‰πàÊÑâÂø´ÁöÑÈòÖËØªÊàñËÄÖÁºñËæë‰ΩìÈ™å„ÄÇÔºàLCTT Ê†°Ê≥®ÔºöÂú®Êñ∞ÁöÑ Ubuntu 22.04 ‰∏≠ÔºåËøô‰∏ÄÊÉÖÂÜµÂ∑≤ÁªèÊúâÊâÄÊîπÂñÑÔºå‚ÄúÈ´ò‰∫ÆÂΩìÂâçË°å‚ÄùÂ∑≤Ë¢´ÂèñÊ∂àÂãæÈÄâÔºâ Â•ΩÊ∂àÊÅØÊòØ‰Ω†‰∏çÈúÄË¶ÅÂÜçÂøçÂèóÂÆÉ„ÄÇÊàëÂ∞ÜÊºîÁ§∫Âá†‰∏™Ê≠•È™§ËÆ©‰Ω†ËÉΩÂ§üÂêåÊó∂‰∫´Âèó gedit ‰ª•ÂèäÁ≥ªÁªüÁöÑÊ∑±Ëâ≤Ê®°Âºè„ÄÇ ËÆ© gedit Âú®Ê∑±Ëâ≤Ê®°Âºè‰∏ãÈòÖËØª‰ΩìÈ™åÂèãÂ•Ω ‰Ω†Âü∫Êú¨‰∏äÊúâ‰∏§‰∏™ÈÄâÊã©Ôºö Á¶ÅÁî®È´ò‰∫ÆÂΩìÂâçË°åÔºå‰ΩÜ‰πüÂêåÊó∂ÊÑèÂë≥ÁùÄ‰Ω†ÂøÖÈ°ªÊ∏ÖÊ•öÂú∞Áü•ÈÅì‰Ω†Âú®Âì™‰∏ÄË°å„ÄÇ ÊîπÂèòÈªòËÆ§ÁöÑÈ¢úËâ≤ËÆæÁΩÆÔºå‰ΩÜÁºñËæëÂô®ÁöÑÈ¢úËâ≤‰ºöÂèòÂæóÁ®çÂæÆÊúâ‰∫õ‰∏çÂêåÔºåËÄå‰∏îÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†Êõ¥ÊîπÁ≥ªÁªü‰∏ªÈ¢òÔºåÂÆÉ‰∏ç‰ºöËá™Âä®ÂàáÊç¢Âà∞ÊµÖËâ≤Ê®°Âºè„ÄÇ Âú® gedit ÊàñËÄÖ GNOME ÁöÑÂºÄÂèëËÄÖËß£ÂÜ≥Ëøô‰∏™ÈóÆÈ¢ò‰πãÂâçÔºåËøôÊòØ‰Ω†ÂøÖÈ°ªË¶ÅÂÅöÁöÑÂ∫îÂèòÂíåÂ¶•Âçè„ÄÇ ÈÄâÈ°π1Ôºö Á¶ÅÊ≠¢È´ò‰∫ÆÂΩìÂâçË°å ÂΩì‰Ω†ÊâìÂºÄ gedit ÂêéÔºåÁÇπÂáªÊ±âÂ†°ËèúÂçïÁÑ∂ÂêéÈÄâÊã©‚ÄúÈ¶ñÈÄâÈ°πPreferences‚Äù„ÄÇ Âú®Êü•ÁúãÈÄâÈ°πÂç°Ôºå‰Ω†Â∫îËØ•ÁúãÂà∞Âú® ‚ÄúÈ´ò‰∫ÆHighlighting‚Äù Âå∫ÂüüÁöÑ‰∏ãÊñπÁöÑ ‚ÄúÈ´ò‰∫ÆÂΩìÂâçË°åHighlight current line‚Äù ÈÄâÈ°π„ÄÇÂèñÊ∂àÂãæÈÄâËøô‰∏™ÈÄâÈ°πÔºåÈ©¨‰∏äÂ∞±ÂèØ‰ª•ÁúãÂà∞ÊïàÊûú„ÄÇ Ê≠£Â¶ÇÊàëÂâçÈù¢ÊâÄÊèêÂà∞ÁöÑÔºåÁº∫ÁÇπÂ∞±ÊòØÂΩì‰Ω†ÊääÁ≥ªÁªü‰∏ªÈ¢òÂàáÊç¢‰∏∫ÊµÖËâ≤Ê®°ÂºèÊó∂ÔºåÁºñËæëÂô®Â∞Ü‰∏ç‰ºöËá™Âä®ÂàáÊç¢Âà∞ÊµÖËâ≤Ê®°Âºè„ÄÇ ÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÂ∫îËØ•‰øÆÂ§çÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™ bug ËøôÈáå¬†ÊúâÂá†‰∏™ Linux     Phiiiil: üç≠ Markdown-Blog Markdown-Blog ÊòØ‰∏ÄÊ¨æÂ∞èËÄåÁæéÁöÑMarkdown ÈùôÊÄÅÂçöÂÆ¢Á®ãÂ∫è Â¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ÂíåÊàë‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÔºåÂπ≥Êó∂ÂñúÊ¨¢‰ΩøÁî®markdownÊñá‰ª∂Êù•ËÆ∞ÂΩïËá™Â∑±ÁöÑÂ∑•‰Ωú‰∏éÁîüÊ¥ª‰∏≠ÁöÑÁÇπÊª¥ÔºåÂèàÂ∏åÊúõÊääËøô‰∫õËÆ∞ÂΩïÁîüÊàê‰∏™‰∫∫ÂçöÂÆ¢ÔºåÈÇ£Markdown-BlogÂÜçÈÄÇÂêà‰∏çËøá‰∫Ü„ÄÇÂÆÉÁÆÄÊ¥Å„ÄÅËΩªÂø´ÔºåÈÉ®ÁΩ≤ÁÆÄÂçïÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Êää markdown Êñá‰ª∂Âø´ÈÄüÂèò‰∏∫‰∏™‰∫∫ÂçöÂÆ¢ÔºåÂÆÉ‰∏çÈúÄË¶ÅÁÆ°ÁêÜÂêéÂè∞ÔºåÊó†ÈúÄËøõË°åÊñáÁ´†ÁöÑ‰∫åÊ¨°ÂèëÂ∏É„ÄÇ Ê°à‰æã TechMan'Blog ÊîØÊåÅÂπ≥Âè∞ Windows „ÄÅLinux „ÄÅMac OS ÂÆâË£Ö ‰∏ãËΩΩ release Ëß£Âéã tar zxf markdown-blog-v0.0.2-linux-arm64.tar.gz ÂàõÂª∫ markdown Êñá‰ª∂ÁõÆÂΩï cd markdown-blog-linux-arm64 mkdir md echo "### Hello World" > ./md/‰∏ªÈ°µ.md ËøêË°å ./markdown-blog web ËÆøÈóÆ http://127.0.0.1:5006 ÔºåÊü•ÁúãÊïàÊûú ‰ΩøÁî® ÂëΩ‰ª§ -h Êü•ÁúãÁâàÊú¨ web ËøêË°åÂçöÂÆ¢ÊúçÂä° --dir value, -d value ÊåáÂÆö markdown Êñá‰ª∂Â§πÔºåÈªòËÆ§Ôºö./md/ --title value, -t value web ÊúçÂä°Ê†áÈ¢òÔºåÈªòËÆ§Ôºö"Blog" --port value, -p value web ÊúçÂä°Á´ØÂè£ÔºåÈªòËÆ§Ôºö5006 --env value, -e value ËøêË°åÁéØÂ¢É, ÂèØÈÄâÔºödev,test,prod ÔºåÈªòËÆ§Ôºö"prod" --index value, -i value ËÆæÁΩÆÈªòËÆ§È¶ñÈ°µÁöÑÊñá‰ª∂ÂêçÁß∞, ÈªòËÆ§‰∏∫Á©∫ -h Êü•ÁúãÁâàÊú¨ ÂÖ≥‰∫éÈªòËÆ§È¶ñÈ°µ Â¶ÇÊûúÂêØÂä®ÊòØÊú™ÊåáÂÆöindexÔºåÁ®ãÂ∫èÈªòËÆ§‰ª•ÂØºËà™‰∏≠ÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∏Ä‰∏™Êñá‰ª∂‰Ωú‰∏∫È¶ñÈ°µ ÂØºËà™ÊéíÂ∫è ÂçöÂÆ¢‚Ä¶  ( 2 min )

}; public class DemoServiceImpl implements DemoService { public String sayHello(String name) { return "Hello " + name; } }; DemoService demoService = (DemoService)context.getBean("demoService"); #ÊÅ≥ËØ∑ÂπøÂ§ß V ÂèãÂëäÁü•ËøôÊòØ‰∏∫Âï•Êä•ÈîôÂë¢ÔºüÂ¶ÇÊûúÊàëÊÉ≥Áî® jshell Êù•Ë∞ÉÁî® dubbo ËøúÁ®ãÊúçÂä°Êé•Âè£ÔºåËØ•ÊÄé‰πàÂäûÂë¢Ôºü  ( 2 min )

    ginakira: Áé∞Âú®Áî®ÁöÑ 19 Ê¨æ 15 ÂØ∏Ëã±ÁâπÂ∞îÔºåÂêàÁõñÂ§ñÊé• 4K Â±èÂπïÊ∏©Â∫¶Áõ¥Êé•‰∏äÂà∞ 65 Â∫¶„ÄÇ Âõ†‰∏∫Â§ñÊé•ÊòæÁ§∫Âô®Êó∂Âº∫Âà∂Ë∞ÉÁî®Áã¨ÊòæÔºåPro555X ÂèëÁÉ≠ÂèàÂæàÂ§ßÔºåÁúã‰∏™ËßÜÈ¢ëÁõ¥Êé•È£öÂà∞ 75 Â∫¶ÔºåÂØºËá¥ CPU ÂºÄÂßãÈôçÈ¢ëÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÊï¥‰∏™Á≥ªÁªüÂç°È°øÔºåÁîöËá≥ÁßªÂä®Èº†Ê†áÈÉΩÂç°‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ÂèóÂ§ü‰∫ÜËøôÁßçÁ≥üÁ≥ïÁöÑ‰ΩìÈ™åÔºå‰πãÂâçÊé•ÁöÑ‰∏ÄÁõ¥ÈÉΩÊòØ 1080 ÁöÑÂ±èÂπïÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•Â∞±ËøòÂ•Ω„ÄÇ ÂâçÂá†Â§©ÊääÂÖ¨Âè∏ M1 ÁöÑ 13 ÂØ∏ mbp ÊãøÂõûÊù•Êé•ÂêåÊ†∑ÁöÑÂ±èÂπïËØï‰∫ÜËØïÔºåÂá†‰∏™Â∞èÊó∂ÂÖ®Á®ãÈ£éÊâáÊ≤°ÊúâËΩ¨ÔºåËÄå‰∏îÂßãÁªàÂ∞± 30 Â∫¶Â∑¶Âè≥‚Ä¶‚Ä¶Â∑ÆË∑ùÂÆûÂú®Â§™Â§ß‰∫ÜÔºå‰∫ßÁîü‰∫ÜÊç¢Êú∫ÁöÑÂøµÂ§¥ÔºåËÄå‰∏îÊÑüËßâÊâãÈáåÁöÑ Intel Ë∂äÊù•Ë∂äÂç°‰∫ÜÔºàÁãóÂ§¥Ôºâ„ÄÇ ‰∏çÁü•ÈÅì‰πùÊúà‰ºö‰∏ç‰ºöÂá∫ M2 Pro/Max ÔºåËøòÊòØËØ¥Êó©‰π∞Êó©‰∫´ÂèóÔºüËÄå‰∏îÊÑüËßâ Intel Áé∞Âú®Âá∫ÊâãÁöÑ‰ª∑Ê†ºË∂äÊù•Ë∂ä‰Ωé‰∫Ü  ( 2 min )

    JavaScript find min/max from array of arrays
    Let's say we have an array of users, but each user is also an array. For the example, we'll use the following data. const users = [ ['Nicole', 31], ['Chris', 33], ['Yaatree', 2], ['Sanne', 29], ]; As you can see, each user array holds two objects: The user's name The user's age How can we quickly return the user with the highest age and the user with the lowest age? Let's find out together. First, we need to find a way to extract the data, and I thought the reduce method would be a great one for that. The trick to using this method is to not pass the initial value. This way, we can only start counting from the actual array of items. const highest = users.reduce((previous, current) => { return current[1] > previous[1] ? current : previous; }); console.log(highest); // [ 'Chris',‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )
    GitHub Vibes on AWS : What Makes CodeCommit Special?
    AWS CodeCommit is a secure, highly scalable, managed source control service that hosts private Git repositories. Simply means we can use GitHub on AWS with any special features. Some of them are easily scale and many more. One of the biggest benefit is can be integrated with other AWS services. Before we talk about it, let me show you how to setup or use it. How To Use CodeCommit 1. Setup Credential $ aws iam upload-ssh-public-key --user-name dhona --ssh-public-key-body file:///home/nurulramadhona/.ssh/id_rsa.pub Create config file under .ssh directory: $ chmod 600 .ssh/config $ cat .ssh/config Host git-codecommit.*.amazonaws.com User (ssh-key-id-goes-here) IdentityFile /home/nurulramadhona/.ssh/id_rsa 2. Create & Clone Repository $ aws codecommit create-repository --repository-na‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )
    A foray into SVM w/ Scikit-Learn
    Hey, Josiah here. Today I‚Äôll be discussing the concept of SVMs (Support Vector Machine), a subset of Machine Learning used commonly for classification and regression analysis. First off, we must discuss how SVM works from a theoretical standpoint. The three lines seen (H1, H2, and H3) are known as ‚ÄúHyperplanes‚Äù, which divide our data into classes. To define a hyperplane, one must follow a simple procedure: Draw a line between the two classes such that the closest data point from each class (known as the support vector) are equidistant from the line. Thus, we have defined a Hyperplane. However, it soon becomes apparent that an infinite number of hyperplanes can be derived. The obvious question arises: ‚ÄúHow do we determine which hyperplane to use?‚Äù The answer is, we use the hyperplane which‚Ä¶  ( 5 min )
    Why ORMs Aren't Always a Great Idea
    Recently, I talked with a bunch of people across several Discord and Slack communities about their thoughts on ORMs and SQL. In this post, I'll be breaking down when we should use each, and the sacrifices we would make along the way. Before we begin, I would like to clarify that I am not writing this post to bash your technology choices. You are welcome to disagree with me and discuss this topic constructively on Twitter or in the comments below. Feel more than comfortable to continue using what you use, this post just contains my views on why ORMs aren't always a great way to represent and model relational data. ORM is simply an acronym for object-relational mapping. In simple terms, it's basically serves as a layer between relational databases and your applications. The standard way ‚Ä¶  ( 11 min )
    Investigating 15s HTTP response time in AWS ECS
    It started innocently enough. During standup, someone mentioned ‚Äúmy branch deployment is a bit slow due to cold-start problem, but no big deal‚Äù. Indeed, cold-start should have no impact on production where the environment is long running. No big deal. But later the same day, I tried checking something in a test system and noticed that a lot of my requests were taking very long time. In fact, I couldn‚Äôt get anything done. Since this environment was also long running, it could not be cold start problem. Cloudwatch metrics on the load balancer showed that all requests return in 6ms or less and that they are all successful. My home internet seemed fine. Time to get an external view. I set up Pingdom to get our /healthcheck every minute and the pattern became clear: 50% of the response times w‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )
    Create a react app with bun
    Want to use bun for your next react projects? Install bun First run the following command to check bun is installed or not bun -v If you don't have bun installed then run the following command to install bun curl https://bun.sh/install | bash Now run the following command to create a react app bun create react [your-app-name] It will create a new directory with the name of your app. To start the app run the following command cd your-app-name bun dev By default bun does not ship with react-scripts so you need to install it first. bun a react-scripts -d Here we install it as a dev dependency. Then run the following command to build the production bundle bun react-scripts build When you run the command above it will build the production bundle and it will be stored in the build directory. scripts to your package.json We can add the following scripts to our package.json file { "scripts": { "start": "bun dev", "build": "react-scripts build" } } Now we can run the following command to start the app bun start And we can run the following command to build the production bundle bun run build By default bun creates react app with javascript but we can easily use typescript by changing the file extension from .jsx to .tsx Get Full Source Code In GitHub  ( 5 min )
    My Most Used Android Studio Shortcut Keys
    Top 5 Android Studio shortcut keys that I use every day, which I can't live without based on my limited Android development experience This article was originally published at vtsen.hashnode.dev on Jun 25, 2022. First of all, I'm not an Android Studio shortcut keys guy because I can't simply remember them. I usually just go to the menu or mouse right click to look for the tasks that I would like to perform. However, there are 5 Android Studio shortcut keys that I use every day that I can't live without. This is only based on my 9 months of Android development experience. Before I know this shortcut key, I do this With Control + / shortcut key, I do this The exact equivalent shortcut key should be Control + Shift + /. Because it requires extra key press, it slows me down. Thus, Control + ‚Ä¶  ( 5 min )
    Hello, World!
    This is my first blog so I thought I should start this blog by writing Hello, World! just like we do with the programming. Hello, World! The first known Hello, World! program was written by Brian Kernighan and Dennis Ritchie, the creators of the C programming language, in 1972. Hello, World! programs have been written in almost every programming language imaginable. As the first program that many people learn, it is generally simple and straightforward. However, some Hello, World! programs can be quite complex and creative. One of the earliest Hello, World! programs were written by Tim Berners-Lee, the creator of the World Wide Web. His program simply displayed the text "Hello, world!" on a web page. Hello, World! programs have been used to demonstrate the power of new programming languag‚Ä¶  ( 5 min )

    Listen to music on Linux with Rhythmbox
    Listen to music on Linux with Rhythmbox Jim Hall Sat, 07/16/2022 - 03:00 Register or Login to like Register or Login to like It's hard for me to work in total silence. I need some kind of background noise, preferably some familiar music. My music-listening needs are pretty simple: I just need a music player that plays my library of MP3 music and streams from a few websites I like to listen to. More Linux resources Linux commands cheat sheet Advanced Linux commands cheat sheet Free online course: RHEL technical overview Linux networking cheat sheet SELinux cheat sheet Linux common commands cheat sheet What are Linux containers? Our latest Linux articles I've tried a variety of music players on Linux, but I keep coming back to Rhythmbox. Rhythmbox is a music-playing application for GN‚Ä¶  ( 5 min )

    Amazon EC2 (Elastic compute cloud ‚òÅüñ•) -Zero to HeroüöÄüöÄ
    In this series I am going to share multiple articles that will teach you from basic to advanced about EC2. So Lets start !!! EC2 is a web service that provides resizable compute capacity in the cloud. It is designed to make web-scale cloud computing easier for developers. Most popular and most used AWS offering. EC2 = Elastic Compute Cloud = Infrastructure as a service(IaaS) It mainly consists of: ‚Äì Renting Virtual machines(EC2) Storing data on Virtual drives(EBS) Distributing load across machines(ELB) Scaling the services using an auto-scaling group(ASG) In this you pay only for capacity that you actually use. EC2 Provides developers the tools to build failure resilient applications and isolate themselves from common failure scenarios. Below are some features of EC2: 1. Reliability‚Ä¶  ( 5 min )
    Manual Testing Vs Automated Testing ‚Äî Top Considerations
    Manual testing and automated testing have their own pros and cons. If you are looking to automate testing of your web app, mobile app, or website then it is necessary to consider the advantages and disadvantages of both manual testing and automated testing. In manual web & mobile application testing, testers manually test the features of a product by executing test case scenarios written for the same. Usually, manual web & mobile application testers are highly skilled professionals with excellent knowledge about the features to be tested and what conditions the features need to pass in order to be successfully tested. Manual testers often use various tools such as data tables, barcode scanners, etc. to automate their task of test execution. Automated web & mobile application testing is per‚Ä¶  ( 4 min )
    React cleaner use of setTimeout
    When working with setTimeout we generally don't have to worry about cleaning up our timeouts. However, introducing it into React can create some nasty edge-cases. This often happens because we want to manipulate data after x time. You might see some edge cases where your interactions seem to be reverted. The general rule of advice is to keep track of the timeouts you create in your code and clean them. To clean your timeouts, we can leverage the useEffect cleanup function. A quick example could look like this: export default function Test() { const [show, setShow] = useState(false); useEffect(() => { const test = window.setTimeout(() => { setShow(false); }, 1500); return () => { clearInterval(test); }; }, []); return ( Loading...</h1‚Ä¶  ( 5 min )
    Django-Start Script ‚ú®
    Hi there üëã New version of Django Start v1.0.0-beta.2 üéä This script saves time for you to start a new Django project. It creates the project and creates the first app and then updates the project settings file and also updates the project URLs file and then creates a views and configures the application URLs file and also creates the index.html üêû Fixes Bugs: Fix the error of repeating the application name within the settings.py file Fix the error of repeating the application link within the urls.py file Fix the error of re-creating a file views.py Fixing the error of fixing unnecessary dependencies Hide the required package installation output from the periphery Features added üßæ: Check to get the latest version of Django-Start Automatic Update Pip Package Manager Create a file requirements.txt Support Linux platform https://github.com/islam-kamel/django-start  ( 3 min )

    Create Flag Using Bitmask and Bitwise Operator in Go
    I revisit some of my college notes, and find that in my first year of college, in Algorithm and Programming Course, Bitwise operator was mentioned but wasn't highlighted. It's either I didn't write the notes on that specific topic (I stopped writing notes in my second semester) or the Lecturer didn't explain anything about the usage. But then I found it is quite useful for Bitmasking. For example, in Unix' file access control it uses bitmask to represent the access: 000 => 0 => can't access anything 001 => 1 => can only execute 010 => 2 => can only read 011 => 3 => can execute+read 100 => 4 => can only write 101 => 5 => can execute+write 110 => 6 => can read+write 111 => 7 => can execute+read+write All of those combination can be construct with just only 3 bits. As you can see, Bitmask us‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )

In response, Musk‚Äôs team asks that the case not be heard until next year, according to Bloomberg. Twitter has pushed for the trial to take place in mid-September, justifying the request to expedite things given that Musk and Twitter‚Äôs merger agreement has an October 24th ‚Äúpresumptive drop-dead date.‚Äù However, Musk‚Äôs team is asking that the trial not be held until February 13th, 2023 trial at the earliest, Bloomberg reports.     Image: Disney ESPN is raising the price of its standalone ESPN Plus streaming service from $6.99 per month to $9.99 per month, a nearly 43 percent increase, beginning August 23rd, as reported earlier by Sports Business Journal. The price of the annual plan is also going up from $69.99 to $99.99. If you get your streaming ESPN service as a part of the Disney bundle, however, which packages Disney Plus, ESPN Plus, and ad-supported Hulu for $13.99 per month (including Hulu without ads takes the price to $19.99 per month), that will remain at the same price as before.     Microsoft could be readying Windows 12 for 2024 in a major shakeup
    Microsoft is changing how it releases major versions of Windows again, and it could mean we see a Windows 12 release in 2024. Windows Central reports that Microsoft is shifting back to a three-year release cycle for Windows, which means the next major version of Windows is now due in 2024. It‚Äôs another big change to how Microsoft develops Windows. Microsoft originally moved away from its three-year cycle with the release of Windows 10 in 2015, prioritizing the idea of Windows as a service. Instead of a big release of features every three years in a new Windows release, Windows 10 was updated twice a year with big new features. For years, many Windows watchers thought Windows 10 would be the last big bang release of Windows, after a... Continue reading‚Ä¶  ( 6 min )

Intel has already informed its customers of the price increases, and it will likely lead to more PC and laptop price increases during the holiday period. Nikkei reports that pricing hasn‚Äôt been finalized, but some chips could go up by 20 percent. Intel already warned earlier this year that it was looking at price increases for certain chips, due to ongoing inflation and the rising costs of materials, shipping, and labor. ‚ÄúOn its Q1 earnings call, Intel indicated it would increase pricing in certain... ËÆ©‰∏öÂä°ËÉΩÂ§üÊåÅÁª≠Á®≥ÂÆö‰∏ãÂéªÔºåÈôç‰ΩéÁî±‰∫éÂºÇÂ∏∏ÂØºËá¥ÁöÑÊçüÂ§±ÔºåËøôÊòØÁ¨îËÄÖ‰∏ÄÂºÄÂßãÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÂÆûÁé∞ÁöÑÔºåÂΩìÁÑ∂ÔºåÁõÆÂâçÊàë‰ª¨ÁöÑÂ∫ìËøòÂú®‰∏çÊñ≠ÂÆåÂñÑÁöÑËøáÁ®ã‰∏≠Ôºå‰πüÂ∏åÊúõÂπøÂ§ßÂºÄÂèëËÄÖËÉΩÂ§üÂä†ÂÖ•ËøõÊù•Ôºå‰∏ÄËµ∑ÂéªÊé¢Á¥¢‰∏Ä‰∏™Êñ∞ÊñπÂêëÔºÅ ÊúÄÂêé Êú¨Êù•ÂÜ≥ÂÆöË¶ÅÂàÜ‰∫´asmÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØÂú®Ê¥óÊæ°ÁöÑËøáÁ®ã‰∏≠ÂèëÁé∞ÂÖ∂ÂÆûÂæàÂ§öÂØπÊúçÂä°Âô®Á´ØÁöÑÂÆπÁÅæÁ≠ñÁï•ÁöÑÊÄùÊÉ≥‰πüÊòØÂèØ‰ª•Âú®ÁßªÂä®Á´Ø‰∏äÂéªËøõË°åÁöÑÔºåÂú®appÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°Ëø≠‰ª£ËøáÁ®ã‰∏≠Ôºå‰∏ÄÂÆö‰ºöÂØπÁ®≥ÂÆöÊÄßÈÄ†ÊàêÂæàÂ§öÊåëÊàòÔºåÂú®ÂêÑÂ§ßÂÖ¨Âè∏‰∫∫ÂëòÁº©ÂáèÁöÑËÉåÊôØ‰∏ãÊõ¥ÊòØÂ¶ÇÊ≠§ÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•ËØ¥ÔºåÂª∫Á´ã‰∏ÄÂ•óÂÆâÂÖ®Ê∞îÂõäË£ÖÁΩÆÔºå‰∏ÄÂÆö‰ºöÊòØÂêéÈù¢Â§ö‰∏™ÂÖ¨Âè∏ÁöÑÊé¢Á¥¢ÊñπÂêëÔºÅ     DartÂü∫Êú¨ËØ≠Ê≥ï
    theme: healer-readable ÂèòÈáèÂ£∞Êòé ÂÖ≥ÈîÆÂ≠ó var ÈÄöËøá var Â£∞Êòé‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂèòÈáèÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúËøô‰∏™ÂèòÈáèÂú®Â£∞ÊòéÊó∂ËµãÂÄº‰∫ÜÔºåÊ≠§Êó∂Á±ªÂûãÂ∞±Â∑≤ÁªèÁ°ÆÂÆö‰∫ÜÔºåÂÜçÊ¨°ËµãÂÄºÊó∂‰∏çËÉΩÊõ¥ÊîπÂÖ∂‰ªñÁ±ªÂûã„ÄÇ var str = "hello dart"; // Âõ†‰∏∫Â£∞ÊòéÊó∂Â∑≤ÁªèËµãÂÄº‰∏∫StringÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•‰∏çËÉΩÊõ¥ÊîπÁ±ªÂûã str = 3; ¬†// ÁºñËØëÂô®‰ºöÊä•Èîô str = "nihao"; //ÂÜçÊ¨°ËµãÂÄºÂè™ËÉΩ‰∏∫StringÁ±ªÂûã Âõ†‰∏∫ Dart Êú¨Ë∫´ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Âº∫Á±ªÂûãËØ≠Ë®ÄÔºå‰ªª‰ΩïÂèòÈáèÈÉΩÊòØÊúâÁ°ÆÂÆöÁ±ªÂûãÁöÑÔºåÂú® Dart ‰∏≠ÔºåÂΩìÁî®varÂ£∞Êòé‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂèòÈáèÂêéÔºåDart Âú®ÁºñËØëÊó∂‰ºöÊ†πÊçÆÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÊ¨°ËµãÂÄºÊï∞ÊçÆÁöÑÁ±ªÂûãÊù•Êé®Êñ≠ÂÖ∂Á±ªÂûãÔºåÁºñËØëÁªìÊùüÂêéÂÖ∂Á±ªÂûãÂ∞±Â∑≤ÁªèË¢´Á°ÆÂÆö„ÄÇ ÂÖ≥ÈîÆÂ≠ó dynamicÂíåObject ObjectÊòØDartÊâÄÊúâÂØπË±°ÁöÑÂü∫Á±ªÔºåÂ∞±ÊòØËØ¥Âú® Dart ‰∏≠ÊâÄÊúâÁ±ªÂûãÈÉΩÊòØObjectÁöÑÂ≠êÁ±ª(ÂåÖÊã¨FunctionÂíåNull)ÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•‰ªª‰ΩïÁ±ªÂûãÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÈÉΩÂèØ‰ª•ËµãÂÄºÁªôObjectÂ£∞ÊòéÁöÑÂØπË±°„ÄÇ dynamic‰∏éObjectÂ£∞ÊòéÁöÑÂèòÈáèÈÉΩÂèØ‰ª•ËµãÂÄº‰ªªÊÑèÂØπË±°Ôºå‰∏îÂêéÊúüÂèØ‰ª•ÊîπÂèòËµãÂÄºÁöÑÁ±ªÂûãÔºåËøôÂíå var ÊòØ‰∏çÂêåÁöÑÔºåÂ¶ÇÔºö dynamic str = "hi dart!"; str = 4; ‚Äã Object src = 34.32; src = "nihao"; ËøôÊ†∑ËµãÂÄºÊó∂Ê≤°Êúâ‰ªª‰ΩïÈóÆÈ¢òÁöÑÔºåËøôÊó∂ÂÄôÊúâ‰∫∫‰ºöÈóÆÔºåÊó¢ÁÑ∂Áî® dynamic Âíå object ÈÉΩÂèØ‰ª•ËÆ©ÂèòÈáèËµãÂÄº‰ªª‰ΩïÁ±ªÂûãÔºåÈÇ£‰πàËøô‰∏§‰∏™Êúâ‰ªÄ‰πàÂå∫Âà´Âë¢Ôºü dynamic ‰∏é Object ‰∏çÂêåÁöÑÊòØ dynamic Â£∞ÊòéÁöÑÂØπË±°ÁºñËØëÂô®‰ºöÊèê‰æõÊâÄÊúâÂèØËÉΩÁöÑÁªÑÂêàÔºåËÄå Object Â£∞ÊòéÁöÑÂØπË±°Âè™ËÉΩ‰ΩøÁî® Object ÁöÑÂ±ûÊÄß‰∏éÊñπÊ≥ï, Âê¶ÂàôÁºñËØëÂô®‰ºöÊä•ÈîôÔºåÂ¶Ç: dynamic a = "hi dart!"; ‚Äã Object b = "nihao"; ‚Äã // Ê≠£Â∏∏ÊâìÂç∞ ÂÄº‰∏∫8 print(a.length); // Êä•Èîô print(b.length); ‚Ä¶  ( 7 min )
